gb.subtitle: This FR speciality car was given an altogether different character to its sister car, the Silvia.
gb.description: The 180SX was introduced in March 1989 as a liftback model of the S13 model Silvia. Production was originally scheduled to end along with the S13 when the Silvia received a full model change. However, the US-spec 240SX with its 2.4L engine showed no signs of slowing down in sales, leading Nissan to break the model away from the Silvia line and continue production. The 180SX was particularly popular with custom car fans who created their own unique cars.

gb.subtitle: The most popular of the 1st generation Camaros, because of its looks and speed.
gb.description: The original Ford Mustang was an unprecedented hit when it was introduced as a compact sports coupé. Aiming to best Ford's success, Chevrolet developed the Camaro as a rival, introducing it in autumn 1966. The 'Z28' is a high performance model that shows the Camaro at its best. This special model features a larger displacement engine and an upgraded chassis in alignment with the regulations of the 'Trans-Am' production cars based on racing vehicles.

gb.subtitle: Popular in drag racing; sporting incredible power from a massive engine.
gb.description: The Chevelle was introduced in the year 1964 as Chevrolet's first intermediate model. The Chevelle also featured the 'SS' sports grade, which would eventually become the most powerful production intermediate model with the release of the 1970 model. The SS 454 was equipped with the LS6 engine, most powerful engine in the history of American cars by catalogue statistics at the time. This made the SS 454 one of the most reliable contenders on the drag racing circuit.

gb.subtitle: The top grade 5th generation Civic balances speed with comfort.
gb.description: The Civic is Honda's longest selling model. The 5th generation 'EG' Civic, introduced in September 1991, was marketed as the 'sports Civic.' The star of the sports Civic lineup was the SiR grade model that featured a 1.6L DOHC VTEC engine. Building upon the previous model SiR which had reached the 100HP per litre of displacement mark, this model produced 9.9 BHP more at 167.7 BHP.

gb.subtitle: The 3rd generation Corvette, with its distinctive exterior and interior, inherits its image from the Mako Shark II design study.
gb.description: The 1968 Corvette Stingray inherits its design from the 'Mako Shark II' concept car which reimagined the Corvette as a grand tourer. In 1969, the base model engine size was increased from 327ci to 350ci, though it retained the 295.9 BHP power figure. The next year saw the introduction of the 364.9 BHP LT1 engine and this version was lauded as the best handling of all the C3 Corvettes.

gb.subtitle: Equipped with fender flares and a ‘G-nose’; the symbolic Japanese sportscar of the '70s.
gb.description: Introduced in 1969, the Fairlady Z was one of the first Japanese cars to compete on the international stage. The symbolic model is the Z 432 which uses an S20 inline-6 DOHC engine derived from the Prince R380 instead of the standard L-type engine. With a maximum power output of 157.8 BHP it also saw use in motorsports. The 240Z is a US spec model with a 2.4L engine, and made 'Z' the byword for sports cars after its success in the Safari and Monte Carlo rallies.

gb.subtitle: A high-powered front-wheel driver sports car with a number of new systems.
gb.description: The FTO was released in 1994, making a comeback 23 years after the release of the original model. The body uses Japanese market mid-size proportions, which was quite rare for its time, and is notable for its relatively large body width. There were 3 engine options available, the '4G93' model 1.8L I4 SOHC, the '6A12' model 2L V6 DOHC, and a high-tuned version of the 6A12, boasting 197.2 BHP. This GP Version R was a high-performance model equipped with sports suspension, a limited-slip differential, and front and rear strut tower bars as standard.

gb.subtitle: The legendary compact, rear-wheel drive car that demonstrated the thrill of driving.
gb.description: Introduced in 1983, this is the 4th generation Corolla Levin. It carries over the floor panel from the previous TE71 and is the only model of its generation to retain the rear-wheel drive layout, while all other Corollas were front-wheel drive. The 1.6L 4A-GEU DOHC engine and lightweight body make for a responsive driving feel. Once production ended, the demand for affordable rear-wheel drive cars only grew, cementing its position as one of the greatest sports models produced by Toyota.

gb.subtitle: The top grade of the S14 adds a rear spoiler and leather wrapped steering wheel.
gb.description: The S14 model Silvia features a larger body than the S13. In 1996, a major facelift was carried out, adding the scowling headlights and a large rear spoiler. The 'Aero' is a higher grade model available for both the K's and Q's which includes special bumpers, front and rear spoilers, a leather wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, along with white meter faces as standard.

gb.subtitle: A serious Supra with a 6-speed transmission and Bilstein suspension.
gb.description: In May 1993, the Toyota Supra was reborn, leaving the long nose behind for a new glamorous muscular form. The 3 litre DOHC twin turbo model with the famed 2JZ engine produced 276.1 BHP, with the highest grade model featuring a six-speed manual transmission and Bilstein suspension. It also featured structural reinforcements as well as tuned dampers and bushings to create a much more manageable beast.

gb.subtitle: An unlikely monster machine born from the elegant lines of the 7th gen. Skyline.
gb.description: This high performance model of the 7th gen Skyline was introduced to compete in Group A races. The RB20DET engine has been modified, fitting it with a stainless steel exhaust manifold and a T04E turbocharger, alongside other changes to the suspension and exterior. It would claim the season title at the 1989 All Japan Touring Car Championship, but it also left fans asking why it wasn't called a GT-R.

gb.subtitle: The 180SX and Silvia in one. An original car born from the love of fans.
gb.description: The 180SX was introduced as a liftback model of the S13 model Silvia. On performance, it was heavier than the Silvia, and lacked rigidity in the rear, but a number of tuning parts were soon released and fans began to create their own original setups. One of the most famous modifications was to outfit the 180SX with the front fascia of the S13, creating what was called the 'Sileighty.'

gb.subtitle: The 4WD midship monster that took Group B by storm.
gb.description: The 205 Turbo 16 is a Group B machine produced by Peugeot for the World Rally Championship. This car won 3 rounds in its debut year of 1984, and another 3 in 1985. Peugeot developed the car further though improving weight, power and aerodynamics to create the Evolution 2 model. This new version would win 7 out of 12 rounds in 1985 and 6 out of 13 in 1986, claiming 2 consecutive titles in both the drivers and manufacturers championships.

gb.subtitle: The Toyota endurance race car that achieved a class win at Le Mans in 1999.
gb.description: In 1998, Toyota developed the GT-One (TS020) with the goal of winning at the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Designed by André de Cortanze, the GT-One features aerodynamics and suspension derived from F1. In 1998, troubles left the team without a result, however in 1999 the GT-One was evolved into an LM GTP car. Ukyo Katayama's team came in 2nd overall, the highest result in Le Mans history for a team of Japanese drivers.

gb.subtitle: The pinnacle of the Honda S, with larger displacement and better performance.
gb.description: Honda's line of sports cars started in 1963 with the super compact 2-seater S500. It was followed by the S600 with a larger engine for more power, then the S800 which features four-wheel independent suspension. With a larger engine than the S600 and a short shift lever easily reachable from the low slung seats, the S800 was met with worldwide acclaim.

gb.subtitle: A fantastic 2-seater Kei car full of driving fun.
gb.description: Introduced in 1991, the Honda Beat lead the lightweight 2-seater boom. At a superbly light 760 kg, the car also boasts an ideal 43:57 front:rear weight distribution. With its engine which uses F1 technology and its short-stroke transmission, the car offers a ride like nothing else. You don't have to go all the way out to winding roads to enjoy the Beat, you can fully appreciate the joy of this sports car on your daily drive.

gb.subtitle: A new design with a lower centre of gravity was the key to victory for this JGTC champion.
gb.description: The 2000 All Japan Grand Touring Championship (JGTC) GT500 class was hotly contested by the top 3 Japanese automakers: Honda, Toyota and Nissan. In the same year, 5 teams competed in the NSX. Of those, the Castrol MUGEN NSX and Takata Dome NSX served as factory works cars. The Takata Dome NSX showed incredible potential, but the season champion was the Castrol MUGEN NSX featured here. It was able to claim the title through careful control of the weight handicaps incurred for good race results.

gb.subtitle: A Kei open-top sportscar capable of circuit driving.
gb.description: First introduced as the 'Kopen' at the 1999 Tokyo Motor Show, this car became Daihatsu's first fully convertible 'kei' class car when it was released in 2002 as the 'Copen.' Thanks to its rigid yet lightweight body and specially tuned suspension, the car boasts impressive handling characteristics. The car also gained a lot of attention for being the first 'kei' class car in the world to feature a powered retractable top, and would be exported to countries like the UK and Australia.

gb.subtitle: Extreme modifications to a front-wheel drive compact resulted in this midship monster born from a utility car.
gb.description: The Renault R5 ('Cinq') Turbo received much attention on its unveiling at the 1978 Paris Motor Show. Originally a prototype for competition in the World Rally Championship (WRC), a production model was introduced in 1980. The car was drastically modified, switching from a front-engine front-wheel drive layout to a mid-engine rear-wheel drive layout. Compared to the basic 5, the new engine produced 1.5 times as much power and 3.3 times as much torque. Debuting at the WRC Tour de Corse in 1980, it swept the field across a number of events, leaving Renault's mark on WRC history.

gb.subtitle: A unique coupé that brings a classic sportscar drive feel to the present.
gb.description: Introduced in 2000 by sports car builder TVR, this 2-door coupé features a detachable roof and an interesting curved yet aggressive exterior design. The engine is an in-house developed 4L inline-6 dubbed the 'Speed 6' producing 359 BHP, and with a body weight of just 1,100 kg this car is capable of absurd performance.

gb.subtitle: An incredibly popular model that triggered a compact sports car trend around the world.
gb.description: This automotive masterpiece revived the lightweight sports cars for the end of the 20th century. Originally debuting in 1989 with a 1.6L engine, displacement was changed to 1.8L in 1993. The attraction of this car is in its fundamentals, the transmission and rear differential are linked together by the aluminium powerplant frame, and all 4 wheels feature double wishbone suspension and disc brakes, all resulting in direct and responsive handling.

gb.subtitle: The 3rd generation Integra Type R powers up, with hand-crafted tuning.
gb.description: The car that familiarized the 'Type R' road-going race cars. Starting with the 1.8L VTEC B18C unit, the engines were hand-built, adding a high compression head and matching conrods to produce 197.2 BHP. The increased weight from parts like the helical LSD were cancelled out with the removal of comfort items to create incredible speed.

gb.subtitle: The first Type R model that dominated circuits around the world.
gb.description: Among Honda production cars, 'Type R' indicates models that have been tuned for performance. In the history of the Civic, the Type R first appeared in August 1997. This Type R was based on the 6th generation EK Civic and featured a B16B model 1.6L inline-4 DOHC 16-valve engine. Thanks to the VTEC system, it was able produce 182.4 BHP at 8,200 rpm without the use of forced induction. It saw much use in racing, and became a favourite for amateur racers as well.

gb.subtitle: The last commemorative model of the RX-7 that ended its 25-year history.
gb.description: The FD3S, the 3rd generation RX-7, debuted in December 1991. While the body width was increased to allow wider tyres, the use of aluminium parts across the body reduced its weight significantly down to nearly 1,200 kg. Though the engine is a 13B like the FC3S, the use of a sequential twin turbo system increased power output to 251.5 BHP/30 kgfm. The lightest model, the Type S, has a power-weight ratio of 4.97 kg/BHP, making it the most powerful in RX-7 history.

gb.subtitle: The final turbo spec model that gained the chassis stability needed to handle the engine power.
gb.description: Released in 1989, the 2nd generation MR2, also known as the SW20, was the successor to Japan's first mass-produced midship, the AW11. Body dimensions were pushed to the limit of Japanese class 5 vehicle size limits, and in contrast to the original featured new rounder, streamlined stylings to express its midship layout. At its debut, the car came under fire for its difficult handling, but later updates would turn it into a well balanced mid-engine sports car.

gb.subtitle: The location of its development influenced its name; a limited model of the V Spec II, commemorating the end of production.
gb.description: The R34 GT-R debuted in January 1999. In contrast to the larger R33, the new car featured a more toned muscular body, being 75 mm shorter with a 55 mm shorter wheelbase. The thoroughly matured RB26DETT was given a further increase in torque to 40 kgfm, and along with chassis improvements the car gained a new level of controllability with more predictable handling. The 'Nür' was the final limited edition model released and was equipped with an N1 spec RB26DETT engine.

gb.subtitle: With fender flares and more torque; the 5th generation Lancer Evo.
gb.description: The 5th model of the Lancer Evolution was introduced in January 1998. Looking towards competition in the World Rally Championship, the body was widened and the 4G63 was tuned for extra torque. The electronically controlled AYC (Active Yaw Control) introduced on the previous model was carried over, and new inverted dampers and a front helical LSD were added for extra performance.

gb.subtitle: The F1 GTR racing machine that took the Le Mans title and GT races around the world.
gb.description: Masterminded by Gordon Murray, this car is a racing version of the 'road-going F1' high performance sports car, F1. From its debut in 1995, steady improvements were made each year with this aerodynamically superior long tail version introduced in 1997. The car would have a relatively long lifespan as a race car, continuing to compete on the forefront under privateer teams up until 2003.

gb.subtitle: A rare model that is the origin of the Honda Type R series, with just under 500 cars produced.
gb.description: A high performance version of the NSX introduced in November 1992. The weight has been reduced by 120 kg through the removal of luxury features and lightening of functional parts. Additionally, every single engine has been carefully balanced to provide optimal feeling at high revolutions. A legendary model whose importance cannot be understated in the story of the NSX's evolution.

gb.subtitle: The legendary machine that brought Mazda the first victory ever in the Le Mans for a Japanese manufacturer.
gb.description: Completing the 1991 24 Hours of Le Mans without any mechanical trouble, the 787B would become the first car to take the overall victory in this race from a Japanese manufacturer. Mazda who began competing at Le Mans with rotary engines in 1974 developed the 787 as their last chance for a rotary victory at Le Mans, as its regulations would soon change against rotary engines. While they failed to achieve their goal in the 1990 race, the 787 underwent drastic improvements to become the 787B.

gb.subtitle: Incorporating electronic AYC; the 4th generation Lancer Evo with 276.1 BHP.
gb.description: In August 1996, the 2nd generation Lancer was released and with it came the Lancer Evolution IV. The 4G63, flipped 180 degrees in respect to previous models, now produced 276.1 BHP with a maximum torque of 36 kgfm. For the rear differential, the previous mechanical LSD was replaced with an electronically controlled AYC (Active Yaw Control) system, allowing for much more controllable handling.

gb.subtitle: The icon of American sportscars, powered by a large displacement engine.
gb.description: Shelby developed the Cobra 427 to win the FIA Speed World Challenge in which they were competing at the time. The car was equipped with a 7L 427 'Side Oiler', a pure racing engine for stock cars. To keep up with its impressive 493.1 BHP the car dropped its characteristic side-mounted leaf suspension for a new double wishbone layout.

gb.subtitle: An extreme midship car with a 3 litre engine, developed by TWR.
gb.description: Originally developed for motorsports, the Renault Clio R.S. V6 features the 3L V6 engine from the luxury Laguna model, producing a maximum 229.8 BHP. In 2002, the 'Phase 2' facelift model increased the output to 251.5 BHP along with other updates to the exterior, interior, and tyre size.

gb.subtitle: The tuned 86, built to order for the Author of the 'Initial D' comic series.
gb.description: This car is the Trueno owned by Shuichi Shigeno, author of the popular 'Initial D' manga which heavily features the 'Hachi-Roku' AE86 model Levin/Trueno. Equipped with an HKS exhaust manifold and Trust silencer, the engine is now capable of producing 207.1 BHP. The car has also been equipped with a TRD suspension kit, allowing for agile footwork and high cornering speeds.

gb.subtitle: The champion machine that won 12 out of 20 races in high-performance DTM racing.
gb.description: The 155 2.5 V6 TI was developed by Alfa Romeo for competition in the Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters (DTM) which had begun to allow major car modifications from 1993. Based on the '92 model 155 4-door sedan, the car is equipped with 60-degree V6 2.5L engine producing 414.2 BHP, and a full-time four-wheel drive system. It would win 12 of the 20 rounds, claiming a glorious title victory.

gb.subtitle: The fully matured model of the 2nd generation RX-7, offering improved sensations as well as driving performance.
gb.description: The FC3S, the 2nd generation of the RX-7, debuted in October of 1985. With a new futuristic look, the car was smaller than the original only in length, being both taller and wider. This new model was also 200 kg heavier. To make up for the extra weight, the car was equipped with the new 13B engine. Performance was improved by enlarging each rotary chamber to 654 cc, and combined with a turbocharger it produced a maximum 182.4 BHP with a maximum torque of 25 kgfm.

379.name: Impreza Coupe WRX Type R STi Ver.VI '99

gb.subtitle: Evolving over 6 years, this is the final form of the GC8 Impreza coupé.
gb.description: This is a coupé model of the Impreza Version VI, released in September 1999. Along with rally car stylings, it also features the Driver's Control Centre Differential (DCCD), an intercooler water sprayer, specially tuned hard suspension, and an upgraded rear axle as standard. The classic EJ20 engine has been tuned to produce 276.1 BHP, making this the comprehensive GC8.

gb.subtitle: A gull-winged coupé that was way ahead of its time; the grandaddy of modern-day sportscars.
gb.description: At the 1955 New York Auto Show, Daimler-Benz unveiled the Mercedes-Benz 300 SL. Though it was capable of an incredible top speed of 161.6 mph, the real attraction was its upward opening 'gullwing' doors that were hinged on the centre of the roof. 1,400 of these 300 SL 'gullwing' Coupés were produced between 1955 and 1957 before it passed the baton to the 300 SL Roadster.

gb.subtitle: 2nd generation NSX with added downforce gained through advancements in aerodynamics.
gb.description: This second wave NSX Type R was introduced in 2002. In addition to the weight reductions and rigidity improvements from the original Type R, this model has received an aerodynamic overhaul producing an incredible amount of downforce for a road car. Carbon fibre parts have been used throughout areas like the bonnet and rear wing. At a time attack on the Nürburgring Nordschleife, this car was able to beat the 8 minute mark which had previously been considered the limit for road cars.

gb.subtitle: The 400-car, limited edition Impreza with identical appearance to the WR car sold out immediately after going on sale.
gb.description: A limited edition model based on the Impreza WRX STi Version IV. The body features blister fenders identical to the World Rally car, and a 2.2L boxer engine producing 276.1 BHP/37.0 kgfm. Though priced at 5M yen, all 400 sold out within days, making this one of the most sought after models among fans.

gb.subtitle: The JGTC machine that was made faster by lowering the centre of gravity and shortening the wheelbase.
gb.description: This R34 model GT-R competed in the 1999 All Japan GT Championship. The wheelbase has been shortened 55 mm over the previous R33 model, and the engine position has been adjusted using a shallow oil pan, greatly increasing overall performance. At round 4's Mine Circuit, Erik Comas and Satoshi Motoyama drove to victory in the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R, winning Comas his second consecutive drivers title.

gb.subtitle: The top grade model of the R33 GT-R, with the ATTESA E-TS Pro system.
gb.description: The R33 GT-R was released in January 1995. In response to the question of how they improved on the previous generation which may well be remembered as one of history's greatest cars, Nissan advertised the new car under the catchphrase the 'Minus 21 second Dream', referring to the R33's lap time on the Nürburgring, where it had beaten the R32 by 21 seconds. The RB26DETT engine was carried over to the new model with improved engine response and torque. The V-Spec model was also equipped with ATTESA E-TS Pro four-wheel drive system as standard, which gave combined control over the active LSD and ABS braking systems.

gb.subtitle: 50th anniversary of Honda; the FR open-top sportscar incorporating their philosophy.
gb.description: Honda's popular 'S' series of the 1960s was revived in 1999. Every part of the S2000 was specially developed to provide the best sporting performance, and as its name suggests, it houses a 2L inline-4 DOHC engine. The 6-speed manual transmission is also a bespoke setup, using a secondary reduction gear to ensure both shift feel and reduced weight. Touches like these provide a glimpse into the dedication of the designers.

gb.subtitle: This midship sports car stormed the rally stage with its sharp wedge body.
gb.description: Bertone unveiled their 'Stratos Zero' in 1970. This wedge-shaped concept car would later go into full production as the 'Stratos'. The body is constructed from a rigid monocoque frame with fibreglass exterior panels and houses a 2.4L V6 DOHC engine. Thanks to the incredible cornering ability provided by its short wheelbase, it performed incredibly well in rallying.

gb.subtitle: A road-going Group C car with breath-taking bodywork.
gb.description: The XJ220 was named for its record as the fastest road car of its time, reaching 220 mph (220 mph). Production was handled by Jaguar Sport, a joint venture between Tom Walkinshaw Racing and Jaguar. It uses the 3.5L V6 turbo engine from the XJR-11 Group C car, mounted to an aluminium honeycomb and carbon Kevlar composite construction chassis. From 1993 onwards it would also compete in GT races including the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

gb.subtitle: Born from touring racing, the ultimate evolution of the 190 E.
gb.description: Mercedes-Benz had been competing in the Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters (DTM) with the 190 E 2.3-16 since 1986. In 1990 they would introduce the ultimate form of the 2.5-16 as the 190 E 2.5-16 Evolution II. The stretched out fenders give the car a striking appearance that is matched by the newly tuned engine now producing 231.8 BHP. Produced in a limited run of just 500 units, the car would see some fantastic results in the 1992 DTM.

gb.subtitle: A dream car in Japanese automotive history, full of originality in both style and mechanism.
gb.description: Debuting in 1967, the Toyota 2000GT is a dream car for many, with its design, engineering and performance all exceeding the expectations of enthusiasts at the time. The car also took numerous victories at the circuit and set a world record when it reached 136.7 mph on the Yatabe test course. Its popularity reached around the world, even reaching the silver screen when it served as the Bond car in 'You Only Live Twice.'

gb.subtitle: An elegant convertible which hides an inline-6 engine under its elongated bonnet.
gb.description: The Z4 is a convertible sports car that debuted in 2002 to replace the Z3. The bodywork is notable for its clean fender lines and the characteristic Z shape press line ahead of the door. It boasts roughly 3 times as much torsional rigidity as the Z3 while reducing weight by 25 kg. It also features a number of new technologies, being the first BMW to feature electric power steering.

gb.subtitle: A stock racing car with an incredibly massive rear wing and extended nose.
gb.description: A homologation model released by Plymouth under the Chrysler umbrella, aimed at competition in stock car racing. The base Road Runner has been fitted with a long nose extension and a massive rear wing to create a unique look. It came with the 369.8 BHP 440 Super Commando engine as standard, with a 426 Hemi producing over 419.1 BHP and a 384.6 BHP six barrel also available as options. It was produced for the homologation period of only one year.

gb.subtitle: The first Type R model of the Integra, aimed to become the ultimate front-wheel drive sportscar.
gb.description: A high performance model of the Integra introduced in 1995. The B18C engine from the Si has been upgraded with high compression pistons and conrods, along with double valve springs with all parts assembled by hand. Body rigidity has been increased while reducing body weight, and the suspension settings have been completely overhauled resulting in sure-footed handling with no tendency to understeer. It is also known as the road-going race car.

gb.subtitle: Transformed into a widebody, the 4th generation Z became a sportscar targeting the global market.
gb.description: The 4th generation Fairlady Z was designed for the global market, largely ignoring Japanese domestic size restrictions. The wider body allowed for an increased track width, giving it new found abilities for cornering. The engine was a 3L V6 in the front-midship position, with the naturally aspirated model producing 226.8 BHP and 276.1 BHP for the twin-turbo model.

gb.subtitle: A unique coupé that tests the boundaries of monoform design.\t
gb.description: The Avantime is a speciality car designed by Patrick le Quément of Renault Design. The novel body design combines the underpinnings of the 3rd gen Espace, which had proved popular in Europe, with a fibreglass 3-door body. While coupé-like, what makes this car truly unique is the B-pillarless side windows and large sunroof which can all be opened. An embodiment of the character of Renault, this car proved that monoform design wasn't just for minivans.

gb.subtitle: The pinnacle of the Lancia Delta, winner of 6 consecutive WRC titles.
gb.description: Lancia converted the Delta to four-wheel drive and equipped it with a turbocharger to create the HF 4WD, a high performance model which was entered the 1987 WRC Group A class. The Delta HF 4WD would later evolve again, becoming the Integrale, which added blister fenders and more engine power. The body and suspension would receive major upgrades each year. Thanks to these efforts, the car would win 8 races in the '92 season, claiming a 6th consecutive World Rally Championship title.

gb.subtitle: A special R32 GT-R with Brembo brakes and 45-profile tyres.
gb.description: The R32 Skyline GT-R would be the first car in 16 years to carry the GT-R name since the discontinuation of the 'Kenmeri.' The newly developed RB26DETT engine was equipped with ceramic twin turbos to produce 276.1 BHP/36 kgfm. The drive system used the revolutionary ATTESA E-TS four-wheel drive system which was developed with a focus on making the car turn. The V-Spec II was a high performance grade introduced in 1994, and was equipped with wider 245/45R17 tyres.

gb.subtitle: The front-engine, rear-wheel drive open-top that started a 2-seater Kei car trend in Japan.
gb.description: The Cappuccino is a kei category sports car released by Suzuki in November 1991. Along with the Honda Beat and Mazda's Autozam AZ-1 it was a part of the 2-seater kei sports boom. The Cappuccino features a long-nosed 2-seater convertible body equipped with a front-mounted 63.1 BHP engine, the most powerful spec under kei regulations. With a 51:49 front-to-rear weight distribution, there is no doubt that this is a true rear-wheel drive sports car.

gb.subtitle: The rally machine that left an impression on many fans, though it only competed for a short time.
gb.description: The ST185 model Celica earned Toyota a double victory in the 1993 WRC, winning both the makes and drivers titles. In 1994, the new ST205 was introduced, hoping for another victory. However, in the 7th round at Catalonia, the Celica was found to have violated engine regulations and was stripped of all points for the season. Toyota reacted to the decision by pulling out of the WRC, ending the ST205's career after just one season. Although it only had a short run, the car's gallant looks earned it numerous fans.

gb.subtitle: The final evolution of the Lancer Evo VIII with updated suspension and low centre of gravity.
gb.description: The 8th model of the Lancer Evolution was released in January 2003. Refinements were made to the ACD (Active Centre Differential) and AYC control systems from the previous model enhancing ride quality. The 4G63 engine's maximum torque now reached 40 kgfm and with the new 6-speed manual transmission, the car can perform its best in all conditions.

gb.subtitle: A monster made for the legendary hill climb.
gb.description: The Pikes Peak International Hill Climb is the world's largest hill climb race, spanning a gruelling distance of 12.4 miles and an elevation difference of 1,439 m. The Suzuki V6 Escudo Pikes Peak Special was developed especially for this race and features a midship mounted 981.3 BHP 2.5L V6 twin-turbo engine. Thanks to its lightweight and excellent aerodynamics, Nobuhiro Tajima became the first Japanese driver to achieve overall victory at the event in 1995.

gb.subtitle: The original hatchback 86, whose lack of rigidity was more than forgivable.
gb.description: The Corolla/Sprinter largely moved over to a front-wheel drive layout in 1983, with the single exception being the rear-wheel drive AE86 model Corolla Levin/Sprinter Trueno, otherwise known as the 'Hachi-Roku'. The body was available as a 3-door hatchback or a 2-door notchback. The engine was a newly developed 1.6L 4A-GEU inline-4 DOHC unit. There were rivals which boasted similar specs, but the Hachi-Roku is still loved by car enthusiasts to this day for its fun and satisfying handling.

gb.subtitle: Based on the Stingray Racer, the 2nd generation Corvette is a true sports car.
gb.description: This car is the reason the Corvette became the king of American sports cars. The futuristic yet elegant stingray inspired body took the world by storm. Its performance is also outstanding with a 5.4L OHV V8 engine producing over 295.9 BHP, along with 4-wheel independent suspension and a short wheelbase.

gb.subtitle: The first Type R model that dominated circuits around the world.
gb.description: Starting with the debut of the original in 1972, the Civic is Honda's longest selling car. 1997 saw the introduction of the first Type R model, based on the 6th generation Civic. The 'B16B' 1.6L inline-4 DOHC engine is able to produce 182.4 BHP despite being naturally aspirated. As is the style of the Type R, modifications like body weight reduction and suspension upgrades have also been implemented. It proved to be immensely popular, seeing use in both major professional races and amateur events.

gb.subtitle: The ultimate Delta set a new WRC record for consecutive wins.
gb.description: After a streak of victories at the WRC thanks to the incredible performance of the Lancia Delta, Lancia would go on to face stiff competition from Toyota in 1991. This led to the development of the ultimate Delta, the HF Integrale Evoluzione. Along with improvements to engine output also came an overhaul of the front-rear power distribution and a stark improvement in handling. The Evoluzione debuted at the 1992 WRC, and would contribute to the company's record of ongoing victories.

gb.subtitle: Only 197 examples of this GT-R were made before it was unfortunately discontinued in the wake of stricter emissions standards.
gb.description: This is a high performance model of the 4th generation 'C110' Skyline. Larger than the previous model, this new body features the same S20 straight six engine as the 'Hakosuka' GT-R and is now fitted with 4-wheel disc brakes. This car was created to carry on the legacy of the GT-R, but new emissions standards meant that it would finish its career before ever participating in a single race. Only 197 were produced.

gb.subtitle: The origin of the Skyline Legend. The legendary 'Hakosuka' (Box Skyline) that won 50 races in a row.
gb.description: This is a high performance model of the C10 model Skyline, nicknamed the 'Hakosuka,' introduced in February 1969. It features bolt-on overfenders and an S20 DOHC engine derived from the R380 racing car. It had an unprecedented racing record, winning 52 races, 49 consecutively before the factory racing team ceased operations. The legend of the Skyline originates with this car.

gb.subtitle: A homologated model with special equipment for Group A racing.
gb.description: Originally a variant of the Celica, the XX became a model of its own in February 1986 when it debuted as the Supra. Among the grade models available, the most popular was the high performance 3.0GT Turbo A, a model made for championship homologation which featured the 266.3 BHP 7M-GTEU 3L turbo engine. In addition it had a wider body equal to the North American spec model at 1,745 mm, as well as reinforced suspension.

gb.subtitle: Powered by a naturally aspirated engine; the fair price and ease of handling are part of the allure of the S13.
gb.description: Produced from 1988 to 1993, the S13 model Silvia garnered countless fans for the enjoyable handling of its compact, rear-wheel drive setup. While the top grade K's model featured a turbocharged engine, the Q's featured a 138.1 BHP naturally aspirated unit. The suspension uses struts on the front with a multilink system on the rear, and was also available with 'Super HICAS' four-wheel steering.

gb.subtitle: Improved aerodynamics and cooling make for the ultimate first wave 'Evo.'
gb.description: The 3rd Lancer Evolution model was released in January 1995. In order to improve racing performance, much attention has been paid to the aerodynamics and cooling, as seen in the now-larger open mouth of the front bumper and the large boot-mounted spoiler. The classic 4G63 engine has been further tuned to produce 266.3 BHP. In the 1996 World Rally Championship, Tommi Mäkinen won the drivers' title in this car.

gb.subtitle: The C4 Corvette with a grand package option befitting its special name.
gb.description: The ZR-1 was a special performance package introduced for the Corvette in 1990. At its core is the 'LT5' engine, which uses an aluminium-alloy cylinder block with a DOHC 4-valve head, jointly developed between Chevrolet and Lotus. While the standard engine produced 246.5 BHP, this new unit produced 374.8 BHP. Its sale price was double that of the standard Corvette, making it a very expensive model, but even so it is rumoured that Chevrolet made very little profit from it.

gb.subtitle: Appearing towards the end of Group C's turbo era, this outstanding car took victory in every round of the final All-Japan Sports Prototype Championship.
gb.description: After it was decided that the All Japan GT Championship would continue with the old turbocharger rules until 1992, Nissan continued development of their cars culminating in the R92CP. With a top speed recorded on the main straight of Fuji Speedway at over 248.5 mph and producing up to 3.5 tons of downforce, the R92CP was unstoppable, winning every race of the season, and closing out the turbo era.

gb.subtitle: This sports coupé captured the attention of all generations with its unique futuristic design.
gb.description: The Audi TT is a sports coupé released in 1998. The base model featured the same 177.5 BHP 1.8L inline-4 DOHC turbo engine as the Audi A3 and A4, with upper grades featuring higher tuned versions of the same engine. In 2003, the 3.2 quattro was added to the lineup, equipped with a 3.2L V6 engine producing 246.5 BHP. This was mated to a new generation 2-pedal manual 'DSG' (Direct Shift Gearbox) transmission.

gb.subtitle: The unbeatable group C car, feared as the return of Mercedes Works racing.
gb.description: The C9 is a Group C race car developed by Sauber of Switzerland. After previously providing engines for them, Mercedes took Sauber on as the factory team in 1988. In '89, the car appeared with an all silver body, inciting flashbacks of the Silver Arrows. In an astonishing result at the 24 Hours of Le Mans, car 63 took first place with 61 in second and 62 in fifth.

gb.subtitle: The series 2 DeLorean, tuned to the request of owners.
gb.description: Formerly vice president at GM, John Z. DeLorean went independent founding DMC. Their first production model was the DMC-12, which used a bold, stainless-steel body. Its gullwing doors were another point of note, yet despite such efforts, company would still go bankrupt in 1983. The owner of the new-born DMC, which would now service DeLoreans, answered demands from fans, later releasing the Series 2 DeLorean, which was equipped with an engine tuned to 197.2 BHP.

1040.name: Ford GT LM Race Car Spec II

gb.subtitle: A dream car by Gran Turismo, commemorating the return of a legend that made Le Mans history.
gb.description: This LM race car is a Le Mans spec style reimagining of the Ford GT, itself a reinterpretation of the 1960s classic GT40 using modern technology. Carrying on from the GT40's historic bid for victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans, this car features a 5.4L supercharged V8 DOHC engine producing 591.7 BHP. It is also equipped with double wishbone suspension and a racing style 6-speed gearbox.

gb.subtitle: The 'Yota-Hachi', quick around corners with its wide tread and low centre of gravity.
gb.description: The Toyota Sports 800, nicknamed the 'Yota-Hachi,' is a compact sports car with a fixed B-pillar type removable roof panel (or Targa top.) Aluminium and acrylic parts have been used extensively throughout out the body, reducing weight to just 580 kg. The 750 cc engine produces just 44.4 BHP but its light weight allows it to reach a top speed of 96.3 mph, which was as fast as many 1,500 cc class cars of its time.

gb.subtitle: Jaguar’s iconic Le Mans car which rose victorious against turbocharged cars.
gb.description: After their successes at Le Mans in the 1950s, Jaguar would eventually return in 1986 with a Group C machine. They would hit their peak in 1988 with this XJR-9. Its excellent aerodynamics and endurability from its simple construction would earn it victory in the Le Mans 24 Hours. This victory earned a place in the history books as they had managed to defeat the long-running champions of Le Mans, Porsche.

gb.subtitle: Nicknamed 'The Vacuum Cleaner', this car took the motoring world by surprise and became an icon in racing history.
gb.description: The Chaparral 2J is an unusual race car that competed in the 1970 SCCA Can-Am series. It was nicknamed the 'vacuum cleaner' for its unique construction that places 2 fans in the rear of the body. Driven by a secondary engine, these 2 fans pull air out from underneath the car with a strong suction force. Effectively, this was the world's first active ground effect car. However, a change in SCCA regulations for 1971 banned the use of any secondary engines, forcing the car into retirement.

gb.subtitle: With welds measured down to microns, Audi’s super sportscar is built to absolute perfection.
gb.description: While developed from the 'Le Mans quattro' concept car, the production version of this sports car was named for Audi's R8 race cars which had performed spectacularly at Le Mans. Made with Audi's ultra lightweight space frame, the car is equipped with a 414.2 BHP 4.2L V8 engine driving all four wheels through the quattro system which uses viscous couplings. In 2009, the 5.2 FSI was added to the line-up equipped with a 5.2L V10 producing 517.7 BHP.

gb.subtitle: The hot model of the MINI, armed with a supercharger.
gb.description: This is a hot hatch model of the new MINI after their takeover by BMW. The 1.6L inline-4 engine has been supercharged to produce 167.7 BHP/22 kgfm, an increase of 53.3 BHP/7 kgfm over the Cooper. Also featuring an exclusive 6-speed manual transmission, this car concentrates all the joy of driving into a compact package.

gb.subtitle: The no-holds-barred model that pushed the Viper sportscar into the realm of supercars.
gb.description: A coupé model developed to harness the full potential of the Viper. The basic construction, suspension and the V10 engine remained unchanged from the roadster RT/10, though power output was increased to 449.7 BHP. Thanks to the new fixed roof however, the car was able to achieve a top speed of 185mph (roughly 183.9 mph) as opposed to the roadster's 165mph. The GTS-R version which debuted at the same time appeared at endurance races all around the world, proving its superior performance.

gb.subtitle: A top-level midship sportscar capable of achieving a top speed of 195.7 mph.
gb.description: The Ferrari F430 is a midship V8 supercar which debuted in 2004. The newly developed 4.3L engine produces 483.2 BHP. The chassis has been developed from the 360 Modena with improvements in stability and downforce, and uses Extra Super Duralumin aluminium alloy. This top grade sports car has a top speed of 195.7 mph and is available with carbon ceramic brakes.

gb.subtitle: The refined Z33 with the new generation VQ35HR engine.
gb.description: An improved version of the Z33 Fairlady Z released in 2007. The new VQ35HR engine has increased the power to 308.7 BHP and the intake manifold and reduced friction have improved engine feeling at high revolutions. Suspension settings have also been changed to create a more flat and flexible profile.

gb.subtitle: The improved Swift Sport with close-ratio gears and a high-revving engine.
gb.description: The Suzuki Swift Sport is a sports model based on the 2nd generation Swift. The engine is a naturally aspirated 1.6L unit tuned for high rpms and featuring both forged pistons and VVT. Minor changes in 2007 took the rev limit up from 7000rpm to 7500rpm, and with a close-ratio 5-speed manual transmission it provides an even more exciting drive.

gb.subtitle: The 4th generation M3 equipped with a 414.2 BHP V8 engine, based on the E92 3 series coupé.
gb.description: The M3 has appeared across several generations of the 3 Series, pitched as a high performance model with strong links to motorsport. The E92 model combines a 7-speed DCT transmission with a 4L V8 engine producing 414.2 BHP. Extensive efforts have been made to reduce the weight of the larger body with the road car weighing just 1,630 kg. It is able to accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in 4.8s.

gb.subtitle: The long-awaited closed-body model, with better aerodynamics and lighter weight for true speed performance.
gb.description: This coupé model was introduced in the Viper's second generation which had evolved as a sports car. It also features the 'SRT' badge found on many of Chrysler's high performance models. A lightweight body with a 509.9 BHP 8.3L V10 engine means this car has the potential to race alongside its international rivals.

gb.subtitle: The last road car worked on by the founder, Enzo Ferrari.
gb.description: A special model commemorating the 40th anniversary of the founding of Ferrari. Developed with the same methods as racing cars of the time, the car used a steel pipe frame with composite materials such as carbon-Kevlar and aluminium honeycomb structures. The power unit was based on the same V8 twin-turbo as the 288 GTO, producing 478.3 BHP/58 kgfm. It would be the last road car that Enzo Ferrari would work on, and retains a high level of popularity even to this day.

gb.subtitle: One of the leading icons from the supercar trend of the '70s, competing for the highest top speed alongside the Countach.
gb.description: A modified version of the 365 GT4/BB, Ferrari's 12-cylinder road car and their first to use a mid-engine layout. The main point of interest for this upgrade is the enlargement of the 12-cylinder engine to 5L, though changes to comply with exhaust gas regulations means the car produces 19.7 BHP less for a total of 355 BHP. Torque though has increased by 4 kgfm to 46 kgfm. One of Ferrari's most unforgettable classics, this car, along with Lamborghini's Countach would become the symbol of 1970s Italian supercars.

1425.name: Ford GT LM Spec II Test Car

gb.subtitle: A dream car by Gran Turismo, commemorating the return of a legend that made Le Mans history.
gb.description: This LM spec race car took the Ford GT, released in summer 2004, and rebuilt it to race at Le Mans. The power output was increased from the 550.3 BHP of the street model, to 591.7 BHP and the body, while keeping the size and shape of the Ford GT, was reproduced in all carbon fibre for a kerb weight of just 1,150 kg.

gb.subtitle: The refined, final year model of the 100th anniversary machine.
gb.description: The Ford GT which celebrates the company's 100th anniversary takes its silhouette and spirit from the GT40, which achieved legendary status after dominating the top 3 places of the 1966 Le Mans 24 Hour race and winning consecutively for 4 years until 1969. The car boasts a 0-60mph time of 3.3 seconds and a top speed of 205.1 mph. 4038 cars were produced over 3 years until 2006.

gb.subtitle: This legendary complete tuned GT-R found a new following after an ambitious restoration.
gb.description: Created by Mine's, the 'BNR34 GT-R N1 base' is a complete tuned model that explores the beauty of the R34 model GT-R, while keeping to the tenets of street car style. From the tuning of the RB26DETT, to the low-slung suspension, to the understated exterior, everything has been crafted under the philosophy of Mine's CEO Michizo Niikura, to create 'a first-class street car'. This car was fully restored in 2021 by Garage Yoshida.

gb.subtitle: An RX-7 tuned by the legendary tuning shop RE Amemiya.
gb.description: The Amemiya µ Boost up 7 is a street machine created by the RE Amemiya corporation, a legendary tuner of rotary engines renowned for their activities in the Super GT and D1GP. This car is known for maximizing the potential of the FD3S as a cornering machine. Among its accolades as a winding road specialist, it was featured in the Japanese DVD magazine 'Hot Version' where it was dubbed the 'demon-lord of mountain paths' due to its unbeatable speed.

gb.subtitle: Development engineers of Gran Turismo participated in the development of the ultimate S2000, built by Amuse.
gb.description: Known for their extensive know-how for tuning the S2000, Power House Amuse's ultimate achievement is the S2000 GT1. Made of carbon fibre, the car's body kit was developed in collaboration with Polyphony Digital. Though the car's width has increased to 1,829 mm, its weight has been reduced to approximately 1,120 kg. The engine has also been improved, achieving a power-to-weight ratio of only 1.79 kg per 1 horsepower.

gb.subtitle: The popular grade model of the S15; equipped with side and rear spoilers as standard.
gb.description: The 7th generation S15 Silvia returned to a more compact model similar to the S13, transforming into an affordable rear-wheel drive sports car. It carried over the SR20 from the models before it, but the running gear and suspension received a major overhaul. Increased body rigidity, upgraded brakes, sportier suspension and a helical LSD all provided a much higher level of performance than its predecessors.

gb.subtitle: Enlarging displacement while shortening the wheelbase; the 6th generation Z focuses on driving.
gb.description: Introduced in 2008, the 6th generation Fairlady Z (Z34) was a full model change with a strong resemblance to the previous Z33 model. It shared the same platform as the V36 model Skyline Coupé and features a lighter body with performance improvements. The VQ37VHR produces 331.4 BHP. This performance oriented model also features optimizations in the suspension and brakes.

gb.subtitle: Special spec S13 Silvia with the popular options set as standard equipment.
gb.description: Produced from 1988 to 1993, the S13 model Silvia garnered countless fans for the enjoyable handling of its compact, rear-wheel drive setup. Of these models, the high performance K's with its turbocharged inline-4 DOHC 'CA18ET' engine was particularly well regarded for its great potential on any given stage. The 'Dia Selection' was later introduced as a low cost model.

gb.subtitle: The first to incorporate new regulations; the GT-R that met the expectations of fans with its overwhelming speed.
gb.description: After a surprise comeback, the Nissan GT-R began competition in the 2008 Super GT championship. Looking towards regulations from the next year, this car uses a pipe frame body and uses the same 4.5L V8 engine carried over from the Z. The XANAVI NISMO car showed incredible speed from the very first round and went on to win the drivers title.

gb.subtitle: The machine that ended the reign of GT-Rs and became champion.
gb.description: The All Japan Grand Touring Championship (JGTC) was held until 2004, before it became the current 'Super GT' series. The Toyota Supra began competition in the JGTC in 1994. At the time, the series was dominated by the Nissan Skyline GT-R, but in 1997, the Supra would finally rip the season title away from the GT-R. That historic car is this No. 36 Castrol TOM'S Supra.

gb.subtitle: The 55th anniversary, 399-car limited edition, super-premium sportscar that was given the name of the founder.
gb.description: This supersports car with a limited production of 399 cars was released in 2002 to celebrate the 55th anniversary of Ferrari. Its sharp-nosed body reminiscent of F1 machines was designed by Ken (Kiyoyuki) Okuyama, a designer at Pininfarina at the time. The body panels and most of the framework is made of carbon composites. The engine is a specially developed 6L V12 producing 650.9 BHP/67 kgfm allowing for a top speed of over 217.5 mph.

gb.subtitle: The high-performance C6 Corvette that once set the fastest lap on the Nürburgring.
gb.description: From the introduction of the C6 Z06 in 2005 onwards, the Chevrolet Corvette has exhibited not just the style, but the performance level of a supercar. The 2008 ZR1 rivalled its competitors from Ferrari and Lamborghini in performance. Not only did its 6.2L V8 supercharged engine produce 638.1 BHP, but it also weighed just 1,508 kg and was able to beat the Nissan GT-R's time on the Nürburgring.

gb.subtitle: The final model of the Countach, commemorating the 25th anniversary of Lamborghini.
gb.description: Introduced at the 1971 Geneva Motor Show, the Lamborghini Countach is the prototypical supercar. The first production model, the LP400, was introduced in 1974 in a limited production run of just 150 cars. 1985 saw the release of the 5000 Quattrovalvole which produced 448.7 BHP from a 5,200 cc engine. The final model was the 25th Anniversary, released in 1988 with 657 produced in total.

gb.subtitle: An icon of exotic cars, its near-futuristic stylings turned heads the world over.
gb.description: First unveiled at the 1971 Geneva Motor Show, the Lamborghini Countach is a truly historic supercar whose design and performance attracted massive attention from the world over. Taken from a word in the Italian Piedmont dialect meaning surprise, the 'Countach' did exactly as its name suggests and Marcello Gandini's sensational near-futuristic design would have a major impact on super sports cars for years to come.

gb.subtitle: Producing an astonishing 562.1 BHP, the V8 mid-engine car that takes its heritage from the F430.
gb.description: Introduced at the 2009 Frankfurt Motor Show, this model is the successor to the F430. The chassis uses an all-new aluminium space-frame and is equipped with a 4,499 cc V8 engine producing 562.1 BHP/55.1 kgfm. The 'Manettino' system which unifies systems like the engine, transmission and suspension, has also been greatly improved. Using aerodynamics technology taken from their F1 machines, the car can achieve 0-62.1 mph in 3.4 seconds and has a top speed of 201.9 mph.

gb.subtitle: No longer the baby Lambo; the Gallardo outgrew its nickname with top-tier performance.
gb.description: Released in 2008, the Lamborghini Gallardo LP 560-4 offers an increase of 39.4 BHP in power over the previous model. While it carries over the four-wheel drive powertrain, the transmission has been replaced with a 6-speed E-gear unit which provides 40% faster gear shifts. Weight reduction has not been ignored either, with the body now weighing 1,410 kg and the top speed increased to 201.9 mph. This car offers the highest performance in a streamlined design.

gb.subtitle: A supersport which carries both the history and driving DNA of Mercedes.
gb.description: Unveiled at the 2009 Frankfurt Motor Show, this sports car features gull-wing doors. The all aluminium body houses a newly developed 6.3L V8 engine producing 563.1 BHP/66 kgfm. The 7-speed dual-clutch transmission has been unified with the rear-differential, and provides 5 driving modes to choose from. In performance terms, the car goes from 0-62.1 mph in 3.8 seconds and is able to reach a top speed of 197 mph.

1508.name: Lancer Evolution VI GSR T.M. SCP '99

gb.subtitle: The optional body stripes stand out on this T.M. Edition.
gb.description: This special edition of the Lancer Evolution VI was introduced to commemorate Tommi Mäkinen's achievement of 4 consecutive WRC drivers' champion titles. Set up for tarmac rallies, the ride height has been lowered by 10 mm and low-end torque has been increased for practicality. It was sold in a limited run of 2500 cars, featuring an exclusive red body colour and seats, along with special alloy wheels and a large-diameter silencer.

gb.subtitle: A car that brings to mind the bold driving of Loic Duval and Katsuyuki Hiranaka.
gb.description: A version of the NSX that competed in the 2008 Super GT championship. The NSX was at a disadvantage this season, along with using the previous year's frame, it was hit with weight handicaps and a narrow restrictor, but engine and aero improvements allowed it to remain competitive. The EPSON NSX finished in 2nd place in Round 8 at Autopolis.

gb.subtitle: Won the Super GT team title with its stable performance on high-speed circuits.
gb.description: A Super GT race car that competed in the 2008 season. Based on experience from the previous year, the front and rear overhangs were lengthened to improve aerodynamics, and the compact body did very well on high speed circuits. While it was unable to score any outright victories, it earned enough points over the season to win the team title.

gb.subtitle: Versatile, inexpensive, and can be raced; the original minimum car that's packed with fun.
gb.description: A car that represents the realisation of the FIAT company's goal of making cars for the mass market. Born in 1957, its extremely compact body mounts a 14.8 BHP 497 cc engine in the rear. While small, the car was very practical, and with its low price tag it gained huge popularity, even garnering numerous tuned models from Abarth. The F model featured front-hinged doors for the first time.

gb.subtitle: The 3rd generation Cinquecento, released after a 50-year hiatus; keeps the cute looks from the 2nd generation model.
gb.description: Thanks to its economical price and charming looks, the FIAT 500 was able sell 4 million units across 20 years from its release in 1957. 50 years after the release of the 2nd gen model came the 3rd generation FIAT 500. Debuting at the 2004 Geneva Show, it would eventually release to massive popularity in summer 2007. The car is lovingly known by fans all over the world as the 'Cinquecento,' the Italian for '500.'

gb.subtitle: An even more aggressive-looking SLR, equipped with optional 19' wheels.
gb.description: The SLR McLaren is a production model of the 1999 Mercedes-Benz Vision SLR concept car. The most notable feature is its carbon fibre monocoque body which has greatly reduced weight. The power unit is a 5.5L V8 SOHC engine with a twin-screw supercharger, connected to a 5-speed automatic transmission which offers sport, comfort and manual modes.

gb.subtitle: The circuit spec Zonda with sequential transmission and a variable rear wing.
gb.description: A track-only development of the Zonda, released in 1999. The midship mounted AMG V12 produces 739.6 BHP/72 kgfm. Meanwhile the wheelbase and track width have been increased to improve stability. It has a top speed of 217.5 mph and can accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in just 2.7s.

gb.subtitle: The Prius that focused not only on performance improvement but also on driving pleasure.
gb.description: The 3rd generation model Prius, the byword for hybrid cars. This model aims to improve not only environmental performance, but driving pleasure. The new body has been given a sharp aerodynamic form that exudes a feeling of speed. The engine has not only been enlarged to 1.8L, over 90% of the hybrid system has been replaced with newly developed parts. In fuel efficiency, the car is able to reach an astounding 2.7 l/100 km bringing a new quality to the world of driving, the joy of fuel efficiency.

gb.subtitle: A masterpiece of tradition, incorporating racing car performance that is not apparent at first glance.
gb.description: A high performance version of the GranTurismo which was introduced at the 2008 Geneva Motor Show. The V8 DOHC engine's displacement has been increased to 4.7L, and the transmission and rear differential have been combined in a transaxle unit. It is also the first in the series to use the 2-pedal semi-automatic 'MC Shift' system.

gb.subtitle: The final word in sportscars that captures the philosophy of the genius Gordon Murray.
gb.description: The McLaren F1 is a super sports car devised by Formula 1 designer Gordon Murray. From the 3 seat layout that places the driver in the centre, to the finely tuned weight distribution, this revolutionary model has so many features to write about. It has been lauded by enthusiasts around the globe for being not only the world's fastest supercar but for its usability on a daily basis.

gb.subtitle: A high-performance model, aggressively evolved from the TT.
gb.description: The TTS is a high performance model of the TT series which debuted in 2008. The powertrain uses a 2L direct injection turbo engine with a 6-speed manual, or 6-speed S-Tronic transmission. The engine block, pistons and conrods are all unique to the TTS, and the turbocharger has also been upgraded to deal with the extra power. The drivetrain uses Audi's proprietary full-time four-wheel drive system and is capable of a 0-62.1 mph time of 5.2s on the S-Tronic model and 5.4s on the manual.

gb.subtitle: The 3rd generation Corvette, with its distinctive exterior and interior, inherits its image from the Mako Shark II design study.
gb.description: The 3rd generation Corvette debuted in the autumn of 1967. Heavily influenced by Chevrolet's 1965 show model, the Mako Shark II, the new Corvette sported a glamorous new coupé body, often referred to as the 'coke bottle' look. At its debut, the car was simply called the Corvette, but in 1969 the car revived the Stingray name and brought with it a bigger engine giving the car a lot more flexibility.

gb.subtitle: The top-grade model of the Challenger, which captured the hearts of many people with its design.
gb.description: This Dodge sports coupé was introduced in 1970 and featured the same E-body chassis as the Plymouth Barracuda. Aimed at the pony car market which was popular with the younger drivers at the time, it was sold as both a hard top and a convertible. The 'R/T' (Road/Track) was the Challenger's high-performance model, set above both the '6' and the 'V8.'

gb.subtitle: A road-going racer that greatly improved upon the performance of the F430.
gb.description: Introduced in September 2007 at the Frankfurt Motor Show, the 430 Scuderia is a culmination of Ferrari's F1 experience and the fastest V8 Berlinetta they've ever produced. Compared to the base F430, the engine has been further tuned, weight has been reduced, and the aero surfaces have been modified. The cumulative result is the car is now able to reach a blistering top speed of 198.8 mph and accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in just 3.6s.

gb.subtitle: The flagship supercar that hits 211.3 mph with a power output of 631.2 BHP.
gb.description: A high performance version of Lamborghini's flagship Murciélago, introduced in 2006. Originally debuting with 6.2L displacement, the transversely mounted V12 engine was enlarged to 6.5L to produce 631.2 BHP. The exterior was given an aerodynamic overhaul and other improvements were made to the gearbox and electronics to match.

gb.subtitle: A 380RS modified by Amuse. A masterpiece of a Z, with major weight reductions.
gb.description: The Version NISMO Type 380RS is a complete tuned car based on the Z33 Fairlady Z built by NISMO. Power House Amuse tuned this car even further, to create the Amuse NISMO 380RS Super Leggera. The most notable improvement is the 140 kg weight reduction, as implied by the 'Super Leggera' monicker, which means superlight in Italian.

gb.subtitle: Known as the most beautiful machine of the V12-powered P series.
gb.description: The 330 P4 was developed to defeat the up-and-coming Ford GT. While only 4 were produced in total, there was a berlinetta variant for high-speed circuits and a spider variant which had removed the roof to reduce weight. It won its debut race at the 24 Hours of Daytona. While Ford managed to take victory at Le Mans, Ferrari would go on to win the World Sportscar Championship title.

gb.subtitle: A mirage that never came to be; a beautiful V12 midship racing car that disappeared.
gb.description: Completed in 1966, this is Jaguar's first mid-engine racing sports car. The low, streamlined body, similar to that of the E-type, is equipped with a 495.1 BHP 5L V12 DOHC engine. While it was expected to perform well on the circuit, management at the time were not interested in motorsports and so the project was cancelled. Often called Jaguar's most beautiful race car, it would disappear into the annals of history without ever competing in even a single race.

gb.subtitle: An ultra high-tech sportscar that achieved ultimate performance with mass-production quality.
gb.description: This supreme sports car was created to carry on from the fanfare and performance of the Toyota 2000GT. It uses a carbon fibre body, produced through automated methods rather than by hand, with the transaxle and radiator positioned in the rear to create a 48:52 front-to-rear weight distribution. The engine is a 4.8L V10 unit with a 72-degree bank angle. The beautiful roar of the engine was tuned with the help of musical instrument maker Yamaha. Only 500 cars were produced.

gb.subtitle: The Mégane Trophy car, with aggressive looks further enhanced by gull-winged doors.
gb.description: The Renault Sport Mégane Trophy was developed for use in Mégane Trophy race which started in 2005. While keeping the general image of the Mégane intact, the Trophy features more aggressive styling with a 3.5L V6 tuned to 355 BHP mounted in the 995 kg body. The transmission is a 6-speed 2-pedal manual transmission with paddle shifters. The suspension and brakes are full racing spec.

gb.subtitle: The final car used by Ford to challenge the Le Mans championship.
gb.description: After dominating the 1966 24 Hours of Le Mans, Ford developed a new test car to meet the changes in FIA vehicle regulations, creating the Mark IV. With its superbly aerodynamic body, the car's top speed increased to 215.6 mph, while also gaining high-speed stability which helped it win the 1967 review race. The car went on to beat its rival by a full 5 laps, taking victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

gb.subtitle: The return of the Alfa Romeo rear-wheel drive coupé, with top speeds exceeding 180.2 mph.
gb.description: The original 8C was named for its 8-cylinder engine designed by genius Vittorio Jano. Behind its classical stylings lurks a 4.7L V8 engine tuned by Alfa Romeo to produce 443.8 BHP, with a top speed of 180.2 mph and a 0-62.1 mph time of under 4.2s, putting some contemporary supercars to shame. Released in a worldwide run of 500 units, it sold out almost immediately upon release.

gb.subtitle: The dream concept becomes a road car. A V8 powered, midship sportscar.
gb.description: Based on the 'GT by Citroën' displayed at the 2008 Paris Motor Show, this model has been developed to be the best road car it can be. The biggest rework in this model was the powertrain, changing it from a high-performance EV to a V8-powered, mid-engine sports car. The unusual armour-like styling was retained, resulting in an attractively unique, high-performance vehicle.

gb.subtitle: Lamborghini’s first supercar that brought fame to the company.
gb.description: Lamborghini's first supercar released in 1966, the Miura P400 was a revolutionary development that instantly made the Lamborghini name famous across the world. A number of incredible people were brought together to make this machine including Marcello Gandini, then chief designer at Bertone, Gian Paolo Dallara, who designed the chassis, and Paolo Stanzani who would later develop the Countach.

gb.subtitle: A beautiful, iconic masterpiece from the '60s.
gb.description: This racing machine was born from the combined efforts of Alfa Romeo and Carrozzeria Zagato. Based on the TZ, the body shell has been replaced with FRP, and the nose and roof lowered to improve aerodynamics. The engine uses the twin ignition head from the Giulia GTA to produce 162.7 BHP, and a top speed of 152.2 mph.

gb.subtitle: The Peugeot LMP machine that dominated the upper ranks of qualifying in the 2010 24 Hours of Le Mans.
gb.description: The 908 HDi FAP was developed by Peugeot to reach the pinnacle of prototype car racing. In 2007 and 2008, it would compete in the events like the LMS to further research and development. In 2009, it would finally beat its rival at Le Mans, Audi's diesel engine R10, in a glorious 1-2 finish. While it was unable to achieve a successive victory in 2010, it still performed admirably.

gb.subtitle: A camper van-styled vehicle that maximises internal space with minimum body size.
gb.description: Dr. Ferdinand Porsche's Volkswagen was developed into a wide range of variants. One of which was the Sambabus, which transformed the car into a van with a large luggage space. By mounting the horizontally-opposed engine at the very back of the vehicle, it was possible to create a wide and low floor space while maintaining the compact size. This versatility gave the model a number of advantages as a commercial vehicle.

gb.subtitle: The first Type R model tuned by Gran Turismo.
gb.description: Starting with the debut of the original in 1972, the Civic is Honda's longest selling car. 1997 saw the introduction of the first Type R model, based on the 6th generation Civic. The 'B16B' 1.6L inline-4 DOHC engine is able to produce 182.4 BHP despite being naturally aspirated. This version is an original tuned model by Gran Turismo, based on the Civic Type R (EK) (1997).

gb.subtitle: McLaren’s 3rd generation supercar, offering a new lightweight body.
gb.description: With the name 'MP4' as if to remind one of its parallels with F1 machines, the McLaren MP4-12C is notable for its carbon-composite 'MonoCell' tub. This feature contributes greatly to the weight reduction of the vehicle, which while having somewhat modest power specifications for a McLaren road car, still manages to match or perhaps even exceed the performance of its rival, the Ferrari 458 Italia.

gb.subtitle: Sporty cars around the world followed the trend set by this car's aggressive style.
gb.description: After its hit debut in 1964, the original Ford Mustang received a major facelift in 1969, with a new, larger body design. The Mach 1 model which featured the 'SportsRoof' fastback body, was especially popular among the line-up for its aggressive look. Its design had a significant impact on sports car styling all around the world.

gb.subtitle: The 1st generation Roadster, tuned by Gran Turismo.
gb.description: The Eunos Roadster (NA Special Package) '89 has been specially tuned by Gran Turismo to create this original machine. The engine and suspension have been modified, and aero parts have been added, but the car still retains the Roadster's characteristic 'Jinba Ittai' responsive handling. A spartan machine that can even take on touring car races.

gb.subtitle: The newly developed flagship model from Lamborghini.
gb.description: The Aventador debuted at the 2011 Geneva Motor Show, succeeding the Murciélago. The body has been almost completely redesigned, featuring a carbon monocoque with front and rear aluminium subframes instead of the previous model's steel tube space frame. With the car now made mostly of carbon fibre and aluminium, it is also very light for a car of this type with a dry weight of only 1,575 kg.

gb.subtitle: A fully fledged sports coupé with sharp cornering ability.
gb.description: The Scirocco R is a high performance sports coupé developed from the basic components of the Golf. The body uses a low ride height and wide track width, and has been equipped with special bumpers, side skirts and a roof spoiler. Major upgrades have also been made to the suspension and brakes. Lighter than the Golf R introduced in the same era, this car has been polished up as a fleet-footed high spec sports model.

gb.subtitle: With a cute silhouette and a rear-engine layout, it is an icon in commercial car history.
gb.description: Often known by its nicknames such as the 'Beetle', the Volkswagen Type I was a rear-wheel drive vehicle with an air-cooled 4-cylinder engine mounted in the rear. Produced from 1938 to 2003, over 21,000,000 cars were produced. The Volkswagen 1200 is the official name for model produced between the mid 1950s and late 1960s which featured a 1.2L engine.

gb.subtitle: The icon of Alpine, the pinnacle of the ultra-lightweight, rear-engined sportscar.
gb.description: The Alpine A110 is a classic French sports car with a historic legacy in rally racing. Utilizing the excellent traction provided by the rear-engine layout and ultralight body, it took the international rallying scene by storm, racking up numerous victories. Originally debuting in 1963 with a 1.1L engine, the A110's displacement steadily grew over the years to keep up with the competition. The ultimate model is arguably the 1600S which featured a 1.6L engine.

gb.subtitle: A Mercedes supersport tailored to FIA GT3 regulations.
gb.description: The SLS AMG GT3 is a GT3 regulation race car based on the SLS AMG. It uses the same basic power unit as the production model. While power figures have not been officially announced, it is estimated to produce over 591.7 BHP. This car began full scale racing competition from 2011, winning 25 of the 101 races it was used in that year.

gb.subtitle: The highest quality and highest performance open-top sportscar, that also has the honour of having been a 'Bond Car'.
gb.description: This luxury convertible sports car takes cues from the classic '507' of the 1950s. The aluminium space frame houses the same 5L V8 engine and 6-speed transmission as the E39 model M5, producing 394.5 BHP and able to accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in 4.7s. It featured in a 007 movie as the Bond car.

gb.subtitle: A special road car named after Alfredo 'Dino' Ferrari, the son of Enzo, who passed away at the young age of 24.
gb.description: An evolution of the Dino 206 GT introduced in 1968, named after the late son of Enzo Ferrari. The aluminium body has been replaced with a steel construction, and the wheelbase has been lengthened to improve control stability. The cast-iron block engine has been enlarged to 2.4L reaching 192.3 BHP/23 kgfm.

gb.subtitle: A stylish 5-door saloon introduced by Tesla, the pioneer of electric cars.
gb.description: The second model produced by EV giant Tesla after their Roadster. The large sedan body features a rear hatch, making it a 5-door. Three different battery sizes were available according to the price point. The top grade Signature Performance model produces 410.3 BHP/61.0 kgfm putting it on the level of supercars.

gb.subtitle: A 77-car limited edition model from Aston Martin.
gb.description: This is Aston Martin's new flagship model released in 2009. While visually similar to the DB9 and DBS, the car is actually a special model developed almost from scratch. The power unit is a 7.3L V12 jointly developed with Cosworth, and is the most powerful naturally aspirated engine released for a production car with an output of 749.5 BHP/76 kgfm. Originally announced for sale in the UK at 1,200,000 pounds, all 77 cars sold in one year after delivery started at the beginning of 2011.

gb.subtitle: The Gran Turismo Trophy winner, with unique asymmetric styling.
gb.description: A masterpiece roadster created by master designer Virgil Exner in 1960. The asymmetrical styling, bonnet bulge and aero fins all give the impression that this is Exner's take on the 1950s race car. It would win the Gran Turismo Trophy in 2011.

gb.subtitle: Attained 2nd overall in the Nürburgring and Spa-Francorchamps 24-hour races. A role model for racing cars that has fought and survived the toughest battles.
gb.description: Based on the E89 model Z4, BMW's GT3 machine began racing in 2010. The weight was reduced by 300 kg through modifications such as replacing the retractable roof with a fixed panel. The engine was also switched out for a 4L V8. The 2011 model added wider fenders and a larger 4.4L engine producing 507.9 BHP. Along with an upgraded paddle shift transmission, this Z4 was able to achieve a number of outstanding results in some of the most hotly contested races.

gb.subtitle: Famous in the 24 Hours of Nürburgring, ALMS, and ILMC. The M3-based competition machine.
gb.description: This GT model is based on the high-performance M3, and has been modified for racing. Many of the body panels have been replaced with carbon fibre, reducing the weight to 1,245 kg, and the fenders have been stretched out increasing the body width by 110 mm. Even with the restrictor in place, the 4L V8 engine still produces 493.1 BHP.

gb.subtitle: The GT3 machine that fought the Nürburgring in 2013 with Kazunori Yamauchi.
gb.description: In 2013, Gran Turismo series producer Kazunori Yamauchi collaborated with Schulze Motorsport. The GT-R GT3 was created especially to participate in the Nürburgring 24 Hours thanks to the technical skills of Polyphony Digital. The data collected from this car was used to improve Gran Turismo's simulation engine.

gb.subtitle: The first sportscar built by the motorcycle company KTM.
gb.description: The X-BOW is the first sportscar developed by Austrian motorcycle manufacturer KTM. Pronounced 'Crossbow', it is designed after the mechanical bow weapon of the same name. With no doors or windows, this 2-seater does away with all unnecessary features. The car has excellent handling and is able to take a maximum of 1.5 lateral Gs when cornering.

gb.subtitle: The 7th generation Corvette, worthy of the legendary 'Stingray' badge.
gb.description: The 'Stingray' name made a comeback with the 7th generation Corvette. The body uses lightweight materials and even with the 6.2L V8 LT1 achieves a front:rear weight distribution close to 50:50, the gold standard for the world's best cars. The Z51 performance package adds an electronic LSD, dry sump oil system, and integral brakes among other features which all together allow the car to go from 0-60mph (0-62.1 mph) in just 3.8 seconds.

gb.subtitle: The Mustang-based car with a great track record in SCCA racing.
gb.description: This high performance Mustang was created by Ford and Carroll Shelby in a bid for victory in the SCCA, an American sports car racing series. The lightened body has been fitted with racing suspension and an LSD, while at the heart lies the 289 engine producing 301.8 BHP. It would dominate the series for 3 years running starting in 1965.

gb.subtitle: Successfully improving the aerodynamics of the original Cobra, a legendary model that dominated races in its day.
gb.description: The AC Cobra had dominated the racing scene of the 1960s, and its coupé version was the Shelby Cobra Coupé. The AC Cobra performed well in races thanks to its excellent acceleration and handling, but fell behind its rivals due to the aerodynamic inefficiency of its open body. Thanks to the coupé body designed by Pete Brock though, aerodynamics were significantly improved, adding over 18.6 mph to the top speed. With its true potential realised, the car would go on to win a number of races over the next 2 years.

gb.subtitle: The 1987 winner of the Pikes Peak, that also set a new record in the same year.
gb.description: Audi took the rally world by storm when they entered their full-time four-wheel drive technology into the 1981 World Rally Championship. This particular model is a version of the Sports quattro S1 rally car modified for hill climb competitions, featuring extremely aggressive ground effects. In 1987, Walter Rohrl would take this car to a record-breaking victory at the Pikes Peak International Hill Climb.

gb.subtitle: The predecessor to the 250GTO, with innumerable wins in the world of endurance racing.
gb.description: The 250 GT Berlinetta was given a shorter wheelbase than its predecessor to increase cornering performance on track. These efforts paid off and from 1960 the car would claim countless victories in races like the Tour de France and the Nürburgring 621.4 miles. 162 cars were produced until 1962 when it was replaced by the 250 GTO, itself based on this car.

gb.subtitle: Individuality and calculated beauty; a car that marked the beginnings of aerodynamic experiments in vehicle design.
gb.description: An aerodynamics test vehicle that was displayed at the 1952 Turin Motor Show.
