Parts of the body shell have been replaced with carbon fibre and all driver comforts have been removed to bring the weight down to just 1,125 kg. The engine is a 305.7 BHP 2L 4-cylinder unit, the same as the normal TTS, but it also includes a 'push to pass' feature that allows it to produce an extra 29.6 BHP for a limited amount of time.

gb.subtitle: A road car version of the Gr.3 4C, which sold 1000 units almost instantly.
gb.description: A homologation model of the 4C Gr.3 which is based on Alfa Romeo's new generation midship sportscar, the 4C, modified to meet Gr.3 standards. The excellent cornering ability of the base model has been given a high-speed overhaul with power output increased from 200 to 450 horsepower, and a widened body.

gb.subtitle: The 6th generation Mustang marks model’s 50th anniversary. Ford's tour de force is sold in 120 countries around the world.
gb.description: This is a homologation model of the Mustang Gr.3, a Gran Turismo Original model that modified Ford's legendary Mustang coupé to meet Gr.3 regulations. As this model is based on a race car, the performance characteristics have been improved with a focus on cornering. This all-rounder is equally at home taking on time attacks at the circuit or drifting.

3301.name: Lancer Evolution Final Gr.B Road Car

gb.subtitle: This Gr.B rally machine is a highly tuned version of the final Lancer Evolution.
gb.description: A homologation model of the Gran Turismo Original Lancer Evolution Final Edition Gr.B, itself based on Mitsubishi's high performance sedan. While created as a rally base car, the almost perfect 50:50 weight distribution, and extended rear wing means that even on-road this car is capable of turning corners in a way unlike any other four-wheel drive car.

gb.subtitle: A Gr.3 road car version of the Peugeot RCZ compact coupé.
gb.description: This is a homologation model of the RCZ Gr.3, a version of the RCZ, Peugeot's elegant flowing specialty car, modified for Gr.3 rules. The car has been reborn as a midship supercar that takes cues from the 2002 'RC' concept, one of the earliest incarnations of what would become RCZ.

gb.subtitle: A road car version of the WRX Gr.B modified for peak performance on tarmac.
gb.description: A homologation model of the WRX Gr.B, a version of Subaru's high performance WRX sedan modified to meet Gr.B regulations. Though based on a rally car, more attention has been paid to on-road performance, adding a race car style front splitter, side skirt winglets and a rear diffuser.

gb.subtitle: This Gr.3 racing Beetle is on an entirely different level to the adorable road-going Beetle.
gb.description: The Beetle Gr.3 is a racing version of Volkswagen's iconic compact, the Beetle, modified to meet Gr.3 specifications. The adorable base car has been aggressively transformed into top class race car, with extensive modifications like changing the drivetrain from front to rear-wheel drive, and lowering the roof to decrease the front cross-sectional area.

gb.subtitle: The 3rd generation Atenza stands out with its beautifully curved body and SkyActiv technology.
gb.description: This is a Gr.3 homologation model of the Atenza, based on Mazda's global market saloon and modified to meet Gr.3 regulations. As a base for a true race car, this model has been transformed into a monster saloon producing over 400 horsepower. The car is notable for its design which has even taken the flow of reflections on its bodywork into consideration.

gb.subtitle: Only 24 units produced. This purebred hypercar was made to rule the circuit.
gb.description: A special circuit-only model limited to a production of 24 cars, the car was developed based on the experience gained from the One-77. The front midship mounted 7L V12 engine produces 799.8 BHP, transmitted through the transaxle transmission. Damping, ABS and TCS can all be adjusted to the preference of the driver. Each lucky owner receives complete technical support from Aston Martin, and a dedicated circuit driving program is also provided.

gb.subtitle: The highest performance model of the Cayman series in its naturally aspirated flat 6 generation.
gb.description: A pure racing car introduced for the Cayman's motorsports oriented GT4 grade. It uses the same 379.7 BHP producing 3.8L flat-6 engine as the GT4 model, but otherwise it has been perfectly modified for racing victory, removing all comfort items and employing parts from the 911 GT3 Cup car.

gb.subtitle: The first 911 in history to feature a midship engine. Different from the production model, this is a full competition spec machine.
gb.description: This race car carries on the spirit of the RSR. It was developed in a completely different process to the 911 road car. The 4L naturally aspirated engine is the first in 911 history to ever mounted midship and produces 502 BHP. At the 2017 Nürburgring 24 Hours, the car put on a magnificent performance sitting in the leading position for much of the race.

gb.subtitle: Toyota's hybrid LMP1 car was developed to claim victory in the World Endurance Championship.
gb.description: The TS050 - Hybrid was developed to compete in the 2016 World Endurance Championship. The car features MGUs on the front and rear axles along with a V6 direct injection twin-turbo engine. The combined power output of the engine and electric motors is 986.2 BHP. The car appeared to be a contender for the drivers title but ultimately finished 3rd in the rankings. It also finished 3rd in the manufacturers rankings.

gb.subtitle: The consecutive Le Mans champion & hybrid prototype sportscar.
gb.description: A prototype sports car developed to compete in the WEC and Le Mans. The 2L V4 turbo engine is part of a hybrid system with an energy recovery system that provides a total output of 887.6 BHP. From 2015 to 2017, it dominated the WEC winning both the constructors and drivers title each year.

gb.subtitle: Taking cues from their IMSA cars, this Vision Gran Turismo represents the future of Audi.
gb.description: A Vision Gran Turismo car created by Audi Design. Two versions were envisioned, one hybrid, one EV. On the hybrid, the rear wheels are powered by a 3.4L V6 turbo engine while the front wheels are connected to an electric motor/generator unit, which combined produce an astonishing 950kW (1,274.2 BHP). The car's appearance is based on the classic Audi 90 IMSA GTO race car.

gb.subtitle: Putting the driver before all else. This car is the ultimate realisation of the McLaren philosophy.
gb.description: The McLaren Ultimate Vision Gran Turismo was developed by McLaren as a vision of 2030 and beyond. Behind the cabin, in which the driver would lay in a motorcycle like position, sits a 4L V8 twin-turbo engine. The engine is aided by high performance electric motors sitting in each of the front wheel 'pods', for a total power output of 1,134.1 BHP.

gb.subtitle: A Vision Gran Turismo that represents the potential of kei cars.
gb.description: The Daihatsu Copen is a convertible that offers the full sports car experience while conforming to 'kei' car standards. The Copen RJ Vision Gran Turismo is based on the 2nd generation model, itself released in 2014. While retaining the 'kei' regulation 660 cc engine size, boost efficiency has been improved allowing it to achieve 146.9 BHP/20.6 kgfm. The car has also been further lightened to 600 kg allowing it to compete on the level of larger displacement sports cars. This aspirational work carries on Daihatsu's fighting spirit.

gb.subtitle: This Vision Gran Turismo was born as an homage to the legendary L45 race car.
gb.description: This Vision Gran Turismo was born as an homage to Peugeot's victory at the 1916 Indy 500 Mile Race. At just 1 m tall the car has a stunningly low slung design and its gradually tapered tail is shared with the Indy winning L45 machine. The powertrain is a hybrid system combining a 1.6L 4-cylinder turbo engine with two electric motors for a total power output of 500BHP/730Nm (493.1 BHP/74 kgfm).

gb.subtitle: This Vision Gran Turismo was born as an homage to the legendary L45 race car.
gb.description: This is a competition model of the L500R HYbrid Vision Gran Turismo. The rev limiter of the L500R's 1.6L 4-cylinder engine has been raised to 10,000rpm, pushing maximum power output up to 580 horsepower. Combined with the 170 produced by the electric motors, the total combined power output is 750 hp. On the exterior a large under spoiler has been added to the front of the car and paired with a large rear wing to increase downforce.

gb.subtitle: Audi's epoch-making LMP1 car which dominated the World Endurance Championship in the 2010s.
gb.description: The Audi R18 was developed to compete in the 2016 World Endurance Championship (WEC). The aerodynamics were overhauled, changing to an F1 style narrow nose with wing, and the regenerative energy output was increased from 4MJ to 6MJ. Though Audi managed to secure 2nd place in the Constructors title, unfortunately Audi decided to withdraw from the WEC at the end of the season.

gb.subtitle: A Gr.1 version of McLaren's near future Vision Gran Turismo.
gb.description: A Gran Turismo Original, this Gr.1 machine is based on the McLaren Ultimate Vision Gran Turismo which was created in a collaboration between McLaren and Gran Turismo. Though active aero parts are restricted under Gr.1 rules, this car still manages to nimbly round corners due to the overwhelming downforce provided by the base body shape and strong mechanical grip.

gb.subtitle: 411.2 BHP of iron will. The high performance pickup from Ford's Special Vehicle Team.
gb.description: The F-Series is a line of full size pickup trucks sold by Ford since 1948. This popular model has been the number one selling car in the United States for over 30 years. The F-150 SVT Raptor, developed by Ford's special vehicle development team 'SVT', is a special off-road model based on the same four-wheel drive system, designed for desert racing.

gb.subtitle: A masterpiece lightweight sportscar from the reborn Alpine brand, combining elegance with performance.
gb.description: The classic Alpine A110 served admirably in rally racing the world over. In 2017 Renault revived the Alpine brand to continue the legend, unveiling the new generation Alpine A110. Featuring an aluminium body reminiscent of the classic A110, this new model houses a 1.8L 4-cylinder turbo engine in the midship position, producing 248.5 BHP/32 kgfm. The special 'Première Édition' was limited to 1955 cars worldwide.

gb.subtitle: 2013 GT Award winner. A monster Nova made with all the best components available.
gb.description: A custom hot rod that appeared at SEMA 2013. The 1967 Chevrolet Nova body has been outfitted with the 6.2L supercharged LS9 engine from the Corvette along with a number of racing grade parts throughout the brakes and suspension. It won the 'GT Award' that year.

gb.subtitle: The BRZ driven by Formula Drift champion Daijiro Yoshihara in 2017.
gb.description: The 2017 'Falken Tire / Turn 14 Distribution BRZ' was driven by Formula Drift champion Daijiro 'Daichan' Yoshihara. It is based on the Rocket Bunny V3 aero kit and is equipped with a 7L turbocharged V8 engine producing roughly 986.2 BHP. Fitted with a 4-speed transmission and upgraded drivetrain parts, it would finish 6th in the 2017 season but left a strong impression.

gb.subtitle: The GT3 machine used by Emil Frey Racing, one of the first teams to adopt the Lexus RC F.
gb.description: From 2015, Lexus began test competition of a specially made race car based on the RC F. They would use their experience from these tests to further development of the car which made its debut in 2017 as the RC F GT3. Emil Frey Racing who had served as the development team on the RC F GT3 took the car to the International GT Open. They would finish 3rd in the team rankings.

gb.subtitle: This extremely rare supercar combines vivid Italian design with American power.
gb.description: The third model by De Tomaso. The Italian style body produced by Carrozzeria Ghia has been fitted with a Ford 5.8L V8 OHV engine. This lavish combination, while less expensive compared to its contemporary rivals, is able to meet them all on performance.

gb.subtitle: An original formula car which recreates the performance of mid-80s F1 machines.
gb.description: The Gran Turismo F1500T-A is a modern interpretation of a mid-80s F1 race car design, often called the golden age of F1 styling. The chassis made of carbon fibre is 4,235 mm long, 2,146 mm wide and has a wheelbase of 2,718 mm. The 1.5 litre V6 engine symbolic of 80s F1 racing, produces 986.2 BHP at 11,000rpm.

gb.subtitle: Aston Martin's next-generation successor to the DB9 brings new futuristic stylings.
gb.description: Unveiled at the 2016 Geneva Motor Show, this is the quintessential Aston Martin. While keeping the silhouette that the company is known for, this car separates itself from cars of the past with its new modern details. The engine is a newly developed 5.2L V12 twin-turbo producing 599.6 BHP/71 kgfm and with the ZF 8-speed automatic transmission, the DB11 is able to reach supercar speeds with a 0-62.1 mph acceleration of 3.9 seconds and a top speed of 206.3 mph.

gb.subtitle: The beginning of a legend. A highly modified homologation version of the E30 3 Series.
gb.description: A coupé designed for touring car racing, based on the E30 model 3-series and developed by BMW M. The car adds blister fenders, front and rear spoilers and side skirts to create an all-new striking appearance. The Sport Evolution is the final model of this M3. It's bigger 2.5L engine produces 234.7 BHP/24 kgfm and would prove itself to be a fearsome presence on the circuit.

gb.subtitle: The 2017 model further refines the GT-R formula.
gb.description: The 2017 model of the GT-R NISMO features various improvements throughout the car. While retaining its bonded body construction and the engine specs, the front window frame has been strengthened to increase rigidity, and comfort levels have been increased for both urban and circuit driving. Aerodynamics have also been improved and thanks to a full redesign by the engineers, the body also generates more downforce at high speeds.

gb.subtitle: 2012 GT Award Winner. This awe-inspiring Mustang conceals the heart of a Ford GT.
gb.description: A monster Mustang crafted by one of Oregon's most respected shops. Everything from the rear seats through to the boot has been taken out to make room for a midship mounted 5.4L V8 supercharged engine from a Ford GT, able to produce up to 850.1 BHP. The car was displayed at SEMA 2012 where it won the GT Award.

gb.subtitle: This race machine took on the Super GT championship in 2016 without its hybrid system.
gb.description: The NSX CONCEPT-GT is a racing machine developed by Honda based on the 2012 next-generation NSX concept, for competition in the GT500 class of the Super GT series. At its debut, the car was equipped with a hybrid system, but in 2016, the car would compete without it due to supply issues with the battery manufacturer. It went on to finish the season in 12th overall.

gb.subtitle: This Toyota/Lexus Super GT car competed under joint regulations with DTM.
gb.description: The Lexus RC F competed in the Super GT GT500 class from 2014 to 2016. New regulations introduced in 2014 meant that the weight of the monocoque and the major parts were shared with the DTM model. The engine used was the same 2L inline-4 turbo unit as Super Formula cars. The 2016 au TOM'S RC F collected a number of points across the season including 2nd place in Round 6, finishing the season in 5th place overall.

gb.subtitle: The 2016 Super GT car driven by teammates Tsugio Matsuda and Ronnie Quintarelli.
gb.description: The new rules for 2014 meant that the car would use the same monocoque weight and other main parts as the DTM version. As such major changes were made to the GT500 spec GT-R, with further improvements made up to the 2016 model. In the 2014 and '15 seasons, the MOTUL AUTECH GT-R was crowned series champion. The team had hoped for a third consecutive win in 2016, but finished 3rd overall.

gb.subtitle: This Vision Gran Turismo is a thrilling embodiment of Audi's electric mobility initiative.
gb.description: Audi Design's electric powered Vision Gran Turismo. All across the vehicle, elements taken from Audi's circuit legend, the 90 IMSA GTO are clearly visible. The car features a four-wheel drive system actuated by 3 electric motors, 1 in the front and 2 in the rear, for a total system power output of 600kW (803.7 BHP). Audi Sport constructed a fully functioning e-tron which would go on to exhibit its overwhelming potential at circuits around the world.

gb.subtitle: First seen at the 2018 Geneva Motor Show. This racing Supra served as a preview for the production model.
gb.description: The GR Supra Racing Concept is a concept model that revives the Toyota Supra as a race car, 16 years after production had ceased in 2002. The 2-door coupé's compact body, which has the traditional long nose, short deck sports car proportions, uses cutting-edge materials and engineering to create superior aerodynamics and handling.

gb.subtitle: This Clio sports model has been tuned by Renault Sport for maximum performance on track.
gb.description: The Clio R.S. 220 EDC Trophy is a sports version of the 4th generation Clio developed by Renault Sport. This 2016 version is known as the R.S. Vision and features a novel new bumper designed to evoke the image of a chequered flag. It also features new LED front and tail lights, and other new design innovations throughout.

gb.subtitle: Subaru's first FR sports car uses the boxer engine to achieve a low centre of gravity and sporty handling.
gb.description: The Toyota 86 and Subaru BRZ sports cars were developed in a tag-team effort between Toyota and Subaru. 'BRZ' stands for 'Boxer engine', 'Rear-wheel drive' and 'Zenith.' The engine combines the classic Subaru 2L boxer unit with Toyota's 'D-4S' direct injection technology. The car would receive almost yearly updates after its release in 2012. The 2015 model greatly improved the handling and ride feel.

gb.subtitle: Devised by F1 legend John Cooper, this very special Mini is designed to win.
gb.description: In order to fully utilize the MINI's exceptional handling, the BMC (British Motor Corporation) came together with F1 constructor John Cooper to create this sports model. The 970 'S' was a version of the car with the engine displacement adjusted to 970 cc to fit racing class requirements. While the standard 848 cc engine produced 33.5 BHP, this version produces 65.1 BHP. Though only 963 such cars were produced, it was very successful in touring car races.

gb.subtitle: Spiritual successor to the Beat. A small yet unadulterated midship sports car made to fit Japanese Kei car standards.
gb.description: The S660 is Honda's first convertible ultralight 'kei' class sports car in 19 years, after production of the Beat ceased in 1996. The newly designed body is extremely rigid, while managing to keep weight in the low 800 kg range. Furthermore, the car features a torque vectoring system that allows it to take corners at speeds unthinkable for a 'kei' car, while achieving neutral and enjoyable handling.

gb.subtitle: The 911's very first GT3 spec model was introduced for the Type 996. It proved to be very popular, selling 1889 units.
gb.description: Originally introduced in 1997, the 996 model 911 was the first to receive a GT3 model. Using the highly rigid Carrera 4 body as a base, racing level upgrade parts have been employed in the suspension and brakes, while the engine uses a GT1 crank case fit for higher revolutions. 1889 units were produced in total.

gb.subtitle: Featuring adjustable dampers as standard. This GT3 version of the Type 997 was introduced in 2006.
gb.description: A GT3 specification model introduced for the 997 model 911 in 2006. Using the Carrera 4 model as a base, the chassis and brakes have been upgraded in the same manner as the previous 996 model. The original 3.6L engine was enlarged to 3.8L in 2008 to produce 428 BHP. It also included electronically controlled PASM shocks as standard.

gb.subtitle: A track-only model that further refines the potential of the P1 hybrid supercar.
gb.description: A circuit-only version of the P1 built to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the F1 GTR race car and its career through the 1990s. The system output of the electric motors and V8 twin-turbo engine has been increased to 986.2 BHP. A large rear wing and other aerodynamic improvements have also been made to optimize its on-track performance.

gb.subtitle: The masterpiece 2-seater sports car that inspired car designers around the world for generations to come.
gb.description: A 2-seater sports car released in 1961. Its refined stylings had a profound impact on sports car design all over the world. The 3.6L inline-6 DOHC engine produces 265.3 BHP, propelling the lightweight 1,219 kg body to speeds of up to 130.5 mph. 7820 Series I models were produced, with most of them carried over to the United States.

gb.subtitle: A naturally aspirated V12 engine with F1 lineage. This masterpiece was created to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Ferrari.
gb.description: A special model commemorating the 50th anniversary of the founding of Ferrari. Developed under the concept of a 'road-going F1 car', the engine is a version of the V12 engine from the 1990 '641' F1 car enlarged to 4.7L and mounted directly to the chassis. Now producing 512.8 BHP/48 kgfm, the car is able to accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in 3.87s, eventually reaching a top speed of 201.9 mph.

gb.subtitle: A historic 1950s race car that won the Pebble Beach Gran Turismo Trophy.
gb.description: A staple of the 1950s racing scene. Starting from the base DB3, the wheelbase has been shortened and the body weight reduced, along with aerodynamic modifications. The inline-6 engine originally produced 224.9 BHP but has been tuned to eventually reach 239.6 BHP. This car won the 'Gran Turismo Trophy' at Pebble Beach in 2013.

gb.subtitle: 2015 GT Award Winner. This 'poisonous' 240Z uses a naturally aspirated RB26 engine.
gb.description: Winner of the 'GT Award' at SEMA 2015. Built by actor Sung Kang, this custom car is built from a 1973 Nissan 240Z. The engine is an RB26DETT unit from a GT-R converted to natural aspiration, producing 216 BHP. The over-fenders and front/rear spoilers are produced by Rocket Bunny.

gb.subtitle: The history model that made Porsche's name as a sports car manufacturer.
gb.description: Porsche's first mass-production sports car, debuting in 1949. Models released from 1955 to 1959 were known as the 356 A. The engine is based on the unit from the 550 Spyder. The semi-racing car 1500 GS GT Carrera version produced 108.5 BHP and is the origin of the 'Carrera' badge.

gb.subtitle: Toyota's flagship FR sports car returns after a 17 year absence with a new short and wide chassis.
gb.description: The Toyota Supra was reintroduced in 2019 after having been discontinued in 2002. This new Supra carries over the straight six engine, rear-wheel drive setup of its predecessor, pursuing the ideals of a pure sports car. It boasts an ideal body balance, with a 50:50 front-to-rear weight distribution and low centre of gravity. The twin-scroll turbo provides excellent acceleration, while the wide body and short wheelbase provide agile handling, resulting in a very attractive package.

gb.subtitle: Toyota's full-size pickup uses unique suspension and accessories to maximise its sporting performance.
gb.description: The Tundra is a full-size pickup truck developed by Toyota for the North American market. Introduced in 2015, the TRD Pro is a 5.7L V8 equipped 4x4 tuned by Toyota's motorsports division, TRD. The suspension has been tuned, adding Fox dampers, while a newly designed bonnet scoop and BBS wheels add to its sporty looks.

gb.subtitle: The road going racer that can handle both pleasure cruises and circuit laps.
gb.description: The Radical SR3 SL is a road-going race car that resembles a small Le Mans Prototype car. It is available with a Ford EcoBoost 295.9 BHP 2L inline-4 direct injection turbo as an option, connected to a 6-speed sequential paddle shift transmission. Weighing just 775 kg, the car is capable of stunning statistics, able to reach 59.7 mph in just 3.4s from a standing start and a top speed of 159.7 mph.

gb.subtitle: The 3rd generation Fit hybrid model utilises i-DCD to further improve energy efficiency.
gb.description: The original Fit Hybrid was introduced in 2010, attracting much attention as the first hybrid in the B-segment. In 2013 came the 2nd generation Fit Hybrid, based on the 3rd generation Fit. This 2nd gen model is equipped with the Sport Hybrid i-DCD system which combined with the 1.5L i-VTEC engine produces 137.1 BHP. In the Japanese JC08 mode fuel efficiency test it achieved 2.8 l/100 km.

gb.subtitle: Both Toyota and Honda provide engines for Super Formula. This is the Toyota engine version.
gb.description: The Japanese Super Formula series switched over to the Dallara SF19 in 2019. It uses a halo system that meets F1 safety standards, and aerodynamic improvements over the previous SF14 model makes overtaking easier. The engine is a 2L inline-4 direct injection turbo with 2 versions independently developed by Toyota and Honda. There is a very fierce development competition within the strict regulations.

gb.subtitle: Both Toyota and Honda provide engines for Super Formula. This is the Honda engine version.
gb.description: The Japanese Super Formula series switched over to the Dallara SF19 in 2019. It uses a halo system that meets F1 safety standards, and aerodynamic improvements over the previous SF14 model makes overtaking easier. The engine is a 2L inline-4 direct injection turbo with 2 versions independently developed by Toyota and Honda. There is a very fierce development competition within the strict regulations.

gb.subtitle: The Group C cars that brought Porsche numerous victories in endurance racing.
gb.description: The Porsche 962 C is a prototype race car that debuted in the World Endurance Championship (WEC) in 1985. Over its career, it would earn Porsche a number of race wins and championship titles. In its debut year at the WEC, it won 7 of 10 races, then in 1986, it won 4 out of 9 rounds at the renamed World Sports Prototype Championship (WSPC). In the 1987 WSPC it would take victory at Le Mans, and 2nd place the next year.

gb.subtitle: An evolution of the X2014 created for the FIA Gran Turismo Championships.
gb.description: The X2019 Competition was created at the outset of the Gran Turismo Championship, aiming to create a race car that was as enjoyable to drive as it was to watch. It is based on the X2014 Standard, but the design aesthetics of the front wheel, rear body construction, and rear wheel covers have changed. Additionally, the engine has been changed from a 2L turbo to a 3L naturally aspirated unit, with the throttle also changed to a conventional system.

gb.subtitle: A semi-race equipped model of the 356A, the car that made Porsche famous.
gb.description: Introduced in 1949, the 356 A is an improved version of the 356, Porsche's first mass produced model. Two versions were available, both featuring a detuned version of the engine from the 550 Spyder. The road model 1500 GS Carrera produced 98.6 BHP while the semi-racing 1500 GS GT produced 108.5 BHP. This car also marks the first appearance of Porsche's now iconic 'Carrera' sub-model name.

gb.subtitle: 3 consecutive victories at Le Mans. This racing Jaguar is easily recognised by the large fin extending from the rear of the driver's position.
gb.description: The Jaguar D-type is a racing sports car introduced in 1954 as the successor to the C-type, with 64 units produced in total. It uses a tube frame with a monocoque construction. The body design by Malcolm Sayer is recognizable by the fin to the rear of the driver's seat. It debuted at the 1954 24 Hours of Le Mans and would claim victory 3 years running up until 1957.

gb.subtitle: A Coronet with a 7L V8 Hemi. This 'Super' machine made muscle car history.
gb.description: The Dodge Super Bee is a performance oriented yet cost effective muscle car unveiled in 1968. The line-up featured 3 different high-powered engines with the 425 BHP 7.0L engine sitting on top as the most powerful. The car was relatively spartan with few comfort items. A facelift model was released in 1970, before being replaced in 1971 with a 2nd generation model based on the Charger.

gb.subtitle: Mazda's compact diesel model offers more luxury than you would expect from a car in its class.
gb.description: The Mazda Demio received a full model change in 2014, reaching its 4th generation. It featured the new 'KODO design' philosophy and had looks to rival European cars. One of the most notable features was the newly developed 1.5L diesel turbo 'SKYACTIV-D 1.5' engine. It would prove to be popular due to its superior fuel efficiency, with diesel models accounting for over 60% of orders.

gb.subtitle: Mitsubishi's purebred sports car features the advanced 4WD technology that made them famous.
gb.description: Debuting in 1990, the GTO was Mitsubishi's first true sports car in many years. The large, glamorous body styling was aimed at the American market. It also featured a number of advanced technologies such as the all-wheel control and 4-wheel steering, electronically controlled suspension and active aero parts. The engine was a 3L V6 unit available either twin turbocharged or naturally aspirated. It was sold overseas as the 3000GT where it found popularity for its aggressive performance.

gb.subtitle: This flagship of the 911 line featured a powerful body design and a turbo charged engine.
gb.description: Introduced in 1975, this 911 Turbo was the first in Porsche production model history to feature the 'Turbo' badge. As this badge suggests, the 3L air-cooled flat-6 engine has been equipped with a KKK turbocharger, allowing it to produce 256.4 BHP. It also allowed the car to reach a cruising speed of 155.3 mph, an astonishing achievement for its time. From 1977, the engine displacement was enlarged to 3.3L and equipped with an air-to-air intercooler, allowing it to produce even more power.

gb.subtitle: The pinnacle of the 6th generation Camaro. This car proved its worth on the Nürburgring with its 649.9 BHP LT1 engine.
gb.description: The 6th generation Chevrolet Camaro was released in 2015. The most powerful model in the lineup was this ZL1, which uses the same supercharged 5.7L V8 'LT4' engine as the Corvette Z06. This produces 649.9 BHP with 89.8 kgfm torque. Furthermore, a 2018 model with the '1LE' performance package, which upgrades the suspension and drivetrain parts, set a time of 7:16.04 on the Nürburgring, surpassing many supercars.

gb.subtitle: Class victor of the 1971 24 Hours of Spa. The legendary machine that made AMG famous.
gb.description: This touring car was created by Mercedes-AMG in their earlier days. The 300 SEL 6.3 was already a very fast car, but with the engine enlarged to 6.8L and some extra tuning, the power output was greatly increased from 246.5 BHP to 422.1 BHP. In the 1971 24 Hours of Spa, it would claim victory in its class and 2nd overall, proving AMG's potential for racing.

gb.subtitle: Featuring BMWs high-revving engine technology, this sports model stands at the peak of the E46 3 Series.
gb.description: The 3rd M3 was introduced for the E46 model 3 Series. The 3.2L S54 straight six engine produces over 98.6 BHP per litre, reaching a maximum 338.3 BHP at 7,900 rpm. In 2003, the high performance CSL model was introduced. Along with replacing the roof with carbon fibre to reduce weight, the engine has also been tuned to produce 355 BHP. This car would see great success in touring car racing and other events.

gb.subtitle: With a total system voltage of 800V, this fully electric saloon boasts both comfort and unbelievable performance.
gb.description: The Taycan is Porsche's first full electric sports saloon. The four-wheel drive system features electric motors on each of the front and rear axles, and has been combined with a 2-speed transmission to achieve both incredible acceleration and top speeds. The overboost equipped Turbo S model produces 560 kW (750.5 BHP). It uses the first 800V electrical system in a mass production vehicle which offers benefits for both power unit efficiency and charging times.

gb.subtitle: This high performance model of the 7th generation Mustang is adorned with the name of a legend.
gb.description: The original GT350R was developed for race competition in 1965, based on the original Mustang. The 2016 Shelby GT350R was similarly based on the seventh generation Mustang, with the engine tuned to 525.6 BHP. The chassis components supporting the engine performance were also upgraded, resulting in a car that was fit to go to the circuit straight from the factory.

gb.subtitle: The flagship model of the Aventador carries the revered SV badge.
gb.description: Lamborghini's flagship models have traditionally always featured a V12 engine, but the highest performance models feature the 'Superveloce' (SV) badge. Meaning 'super fast' in Italian, this naming has its roots in the legendary classic Miura. The Aventador's SV model was introduced in 2015 and features an extra 49.3 BHP over the base model for a maximum output of 739.6 BHP.

gb.subtitle: Only 1270 examples of this midship supercar were produced from 2003 to 2006.
gb.description: The Porsche Carrera GT is a mid-ship super sports car that was produced between 2003 and 2006, totalling 1270 units. The chassis is based around a lightweight yet rigid carbon fibre monocoque, with carbon fibre subframes to mount the engine and rear suspension. The engine is a 5.7L naturally aspirated V10 unit based on a racing engine and produced 603.5 BHP. This is linked to a 6-speed manual transmission.

gb.subtitle: Aston Martin's return to international motorsports. A GT1 race car based on the DB9.
gb.description: The Aston Martin DBR9 GT1 was produced from 2005 by Aston Martin Racing for the GT1 category and is based on the DB9. The body has been lightened with carbon fibre construction and features a 5.9L V12 engine mated to a 6-speed sequential transmission. In its debut race, it claimed victory at the 12 Hours of Sebring and then went on to win the GT1 class at the 24 Hours of Le Mans twice, running in 2007 and 2008.

gb.subtitle: A fully electric sports car that combines Jaguar racing tradition with the latest in technology.
gb.description: This Vision Gran Turismo was created by Jaguar Advanced Design. This fully electric model carries on the lineage of historic Jaguar race cars like the C, D and E-types, featuring not only elegance by a low centre of mass and perfect weight distribution. Sitting in the cockpit, all information necessary to the driver is displayed near seamlessly over the road ahead, resulting in a thrilling race experience through digital means.

gb.subtitle: Replacing the heavy V12 with a V8, this was the race car that dominated the FIA GT competition.
gb.description: In order to compete in the FIA GT Championship which had begun in 1997, Mercedes-Benz and AMG developed the CLK-GTR in just 128 days. It featured V12 engine and claimed a double victory winning both the team and driver titles. The CLK-LM was introduced the next year as an evolution model. It would debut at the 24 Hours of Le Mans and went on to win all 10 rounds of the FIA GT Championship, claiming the season title.

gb.subtitle: The 3rd generation CTR features a wealth of original developments by Ruf including a midship engine mounting.
gb.description: Released in 2007, the RUF CTR3 is the successor to the CTR and CTR2. While previous models were based on the Porsche 930 and 993 Turbo, the CTR3 was designed and developed from scratch by RUF. It uses a midship layout with a 3.8L flat-6 intercooled twin turbo engine. It has a top speed of 236.1 mph and a 0-62.1 mph acceleration time of 3.2s.

gb.subtitle: The Supra returns after 17 years away. This racing version competed at the Nürburgring in 2019.
gb.description: The rebirth of a Toyota flagship sports car lost for 17 years, the GR Supra carries over the classic rear-wheel drive layout and straight six engine in a new 2-seater package with an advanced body and twin-scroll turbocharger. It made its Nürburgring 24 Hours debut in 2018, competed in the SP8T class in 2019, completing the race 3rd in class, 41st overall. This solidified the GR Supra's image as a fighting sports car.

gb.subtitle: A road-going version of the 911 GT1 which was developed by Porsche to claim victory in GT racing.
gb.description: The 911 GT1 Strassenversion is a road-legal version of the 911 GT1 race car which Porsche had developed for GT races between 1996 and 1998. The lights have been converted to the same configuration as the type 996, but the basic construction of the car is almost exactly the same as the racing version. In order to meet emissions requirements, the engine has been detuned to 536.5 BHP and yet the car is still capable of a 0-62.1 mph time of 3.7s and a top speed of 191.4 mph.

gb.subtitle: A bold front end design breathes new life into the Crown's 14th generation.
gb.description: The Toyota Crown received a full model change in 2012 to become its 14th generation model with a new front mask. The lineup featured a more reserved 'Royal' version and a sporty 'Athlete' version. The Royal model used a crown as a design motif, while the Athlete has a sharper look with themes of lightning bolts. This created a whole new look while retaining the key concepts of previous models.

gb.subtitle: The Ford GT returns for a 2nd generation with overhauled aerodynamics.
gb.description: From 2005 to 2006, Ford produced the Ford GT, a remake of the GT40, but in 2015 they would announce a 2nd generation model. This 2nd gen model, while retaining the flow of the GT40, adopted an extensively aerodynamic design. It uses a carbon fibre cell with aluminium subframes to reduce weight and is capable of a top speed of 216.2 mph.

gb.subtitle: The grandfather of all hot hatches balances everyday usability with the fun of driving.
gb.description: The Volkswagen Golf was released in 1974 and found great popularity as the forerunner of the compact car. The 'GTI' sport model was equipped with a 1.6L inline-4 SOHC engine using of Bosch fuel injectors which was able to produce 108.5 BHP. The GTI combined high performance with practicality, rewriting the rules for sports driving.

gb.subtitle: A circuit focused version of the Type 993, the final air-cooled 911.
gb.description: The 4th gen type 993 Porsche 911 was introduced in a full model change in 1993. In 1995 came the Carrera RS with a more rigid yet lighter body and a 295.9 BHP 3.8L flat-6 engine. The lineup also featured the Carrera RS Club Sport. Set up for on-track usage, it included a large front spoiler and rear wing, as well as a welded roll cage.

gb.subtitle: An evolution model of Audi's R8 LMS which itself competed in various GT3 events across the globe.
gb.description: An evolution model of the R8 LMS. Cooling and aerodynamics have been improved over the R8 LMS, while the entire drivetrain has been upgraded to increase reliability in competition. Engine power itself has not changed, but body weight has been reduced by 25 kg, allowing for extra freedom in weight balance when adding ballast. Debuting in autumn 2018, it would soon prove its potential by winning the Gulf 12 Hours at the end of the year.

gb.subtitle: The ultra high performance Charger that set a world speed record.
gb.description: Introduced in 2014, the Charger SRT Hellcat is perhaps the most powerful model in the history of the Dodge Charger, which has continued since 1966. Developed by SRT, Chrysler's high-performance development team, the car produces 707.1 BHP with a top speed of 204 mph. This safety car version is a Gran Turismo Original model.

gb.subtitle: A safety car version of the Mégane RS Trophy to patrol the circuit.
gb.description: This fictional safety car is based on the Mégane R.S. Trophy, which was released in a limited run of 500 cars in 2011. The 'R.S.' is a high performance version of the Mégane created by Renault Sport, but the Trophy version modifies this even further with an increased engine output and extensive suspension tuning in a bid to create the world's fasted front-wheel drive production car.

gb.subtitle: A safety car spec Crown Athlete made to patrol the circuit.
gb.description: The Toyota Crown received a full model change in 2012 to become its 14th generation model with a new front mask. The lineup featured a more reserved 'Royal' version and a sporty 'Athlete' version. 4 different power units were available across the whole series: a 3.5L V6, a 2.5L V6, a 2.5L inline-4 hybrid or a 2L inline-4 turbo. This safety car version is a Gran Turismo Original design.

gb.subtitle: Attractive in its simplicity, this single seater sports car harks back to formula cars of a previous era.
gb.description: This car was built by Britain's Briggs Automotive Company to create 'a road vehicle that offers the most authentic and pure driving experience.' The one-seater chassis uses a tubular frame with a carbon fibre shell and is equipped with a Cosworth-tuned 2.5L Ford Duratec engine. Extremely lightweight at just 580 kg, it can accelerate from 0-60mph in just 2.8s and has a top speed of 170.3 mph, specs to rival an F3 car.

gb.subtitle: The prototype race car that gave Porsche its first victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans.
gb.description: The 917K is a prototype racing car designed by Porsche for use in sports car racing. While weighing just 800 kg, the 1970 917's engine was able to produce up to 591.7 BHP in its most powerful configuration. In 1970, its second year of competition, it was nearly unrivalled, winning 7 out of 10 rounds in the International Championship for Makes, and gave Porsche their long-awaited first victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

gb.subtitle: The peak of the Giulia line-up, this model celebrates 110 years of Alfa Romeo.
gb.description: In 2020, Alfa Romeo celebrated the 110th anniversary of their founding with the release of the 'GTA' and 'GTAm' special models of the Giulia. The output of the 2.9L V6 twin-turbo engine has been increased to 532.5 BHP, with further performance improvements in the form of weight reduction and an increased track width. The GTAm model is also designed with circuit use in mind, adding a large front splitter, carbon fibre rear wing and roll bars for a hardcore setup.

gb.subtitle: The 2nd generation of Audi's road going sports car which shares the name of the Le Mans winning R8.
gb.description: The second generation model of Audi's road car that carries the name of their prototype race car that competed in the 24 Hours of Le Mans. This new model carries over the image of its predecessor while updating the Audi space frame construction and 'quattro' four-wheel drive system. This V10 Plus is a high performance model which further tunes the 5.2L V10 engine to 601.6 BHP. It also features a fixed rear wing and a mechanical LSD as standard.

gb.subtitle: Numerous chassis performance and cosmetic improvements have been made by STI for the highest grade model of the BRZ.
gb.description: The BRZ STI Sport was introduced in 2017 as the top grade model of the BRZ lineup. It was developed in a joint effort between Subaru and their motorsports division, STI (Subaru Tecnica International). The most notable change is the body setup. Handling response and stability have been improved through the use of STI's proprietary Flexible V-Bar and Flexible Draw Stiffener parts, while specially developed suspension parts have increased agility.

gb.subtitle: This near futuristic single seater sports concept carries the core concepts of Lamborghini's design DNA.
gb.description: This Vision Gran Turismo was born from the passion and technical prowess of the Team of Centro Stile Lamborghini. Though the chief design motifs of the 'Y' and hexagonal shapes, it also resembles the silhouette of the classic Stratos Zero in its side profile. The powertrain uses a V12 engine with a supercapacitor hybrid system, derived from the Sián FKP 37. In a stylish touch, a glimpse of this system can be seen from outside the vehicle.

gb.subtitle: Equipped with an 8 cylinder DOHC engine, this exquisite coupé  was produced by Alfa Romeo in the pre-war period.
gb.description: As its name might suggest, the Alfa Romeo 8C 2900B Touring Berlinetta is an exquisite coupé with bodywork produced by Carrozzeria Touring in their superleggera process. '8C' refers to the engine's 8 cylinders. The water cooled inline-8 engine was created by genius designer Vittorio Jano, and in performance terms pushes the car into racing car territory. It is believed that only 5 were produced in total.

gb.subtitle: This 'road-legal race car' evokes the image of the much celebrated 300SL sports car.
gb.description: A 'road-going race car' created from the AMG GT. The exterior features a wide body with stretched out fenders and an active aerodynamics system, while the front grille features strong vertical lines. The 4L V8 twin-turbo engine has been tuned to produce 576.9 BHP and 71.3 kgfm. This car is also notable for being the first Mercedes-AMG to feature four-wheel steering.

gb.subtitle: This virtual EV race car is a glimpse into the future of Jaguar.
gb.description: Jaguar's second Vision Gran Turismo was designed by Jaguar with engineering touches from Jaguar Special Vehicles (SV). The elegant body design remains, but the aerodynamics have been completely redesigned to produce maximum downforce. The powertrain utilizes the company's experience in Formula E, featuring 4 electric motors. The battery also features the latest liquid nitrogen cooling system.

gb.subtitle: The 2020 Supra features a significant power boost to the 3L turbo model.
gb.description: The Toyota Supra was reintroduced in 2019 after having been discontinued in 2002. This new Supra carries over the straight six engine, rear-wheel drive setup of its predecessor, pursuing the ideals of a pure sports car. It boasts an ideal body balance, with a 50:50 front-to-rear weight distribution and low centre of gravity. The twin-scroll turbo provides excellent acceleration, while the wide body and short wheelbase provide agile handling, resulting in a very attractive package.

gb.subtitle: Mazda's dream rotary race car.
gb.description: The MAZDA RX-VISION is a concept car announced at the 2015 Tokyo Motor Show. The beauty of the base design has been given a more aggressive reinterpretation as a race car. In order to meet the power demands of the Gr.3 class, the lightweight body has been equipped with a 4-rotor engine inspired by the classic 787B engine concept and recreated using the latest SKYACTIV technology to provide unprecedented performance.

gb.subtitle: This RS model of the 3rd generation Focus is the first to use 4WD to offer even higher levels of competitive performance.
gb.description: Introduced in 2018, the 4th generation Ford Focus featured a high performance 'RS' model in the line-up. This 4th gen RS model was the first to feature four-wheel drive and had adjustable torque distribution. It also features new selectable drive modes like 'Track' and 'Drift' alongside improvements to the chassis and dampers. The engine is a 2.3L inline-4 'EcoBoost' unit producing 345.2 BHP. This car boasts excellent performance with a 0-62.1 mph time of 4.7s and a top speed of 165.3 mph.

gb.subtitle: This high-output model of the Merak has been tuned for even sharper performance.
gb.description: This midship sports car debuted in 1972 as the sister car to the Bora. While the Bora had a V8, the Merak used the smaller 3L V6 engine from the Citroën SM and implemented a 2+2 layout with the extra space available. The SS is a high performance model introduced in 1975. Engine output has been increased through a higher compression ratio, raising the top speed from 139.8 mph to 155.3 mph.

gb.subtitle: This lightweight model of the 3.0 CS was developed for competition in touring car racing.
gb.description: The 3.0 CSL was introduced in 1971 as a racing homologation model of the BMW 3.0 CS, a sports coupé with a powerful 3L straight six engine. The engine displacement was increased from 2,985 cc to 3,003 cc in 1972, and again to 3,155 cc in 1973 in evolution models which saw incredible success on the European touring car scene.

gb.subtitle: It took 10,000 hours to complete this 2016 Gran Turismo Award winner.
gb.description: The 'Gran Turismo Award' is given to the based custom cars on display at SEMA. In 2016, the 14th such award was given to the Wicked Fabrications GT 51, built from a 1951 Ford Custom Club Coupe by a team of customisation specialists for former racing driver Bruce Leven. The work took an estimated 10,000 hours to complete.

gb.subtitle: The '9.5', the final 4G63 powered Lancer Evolution.
gb.description: The Lancer Evolution IX GSR features the initials of Mitsubishi Racing (MR). Performance has been enhanced across the board, with the engine's MIVEC settings tuned to improve turbo response, while the suspension has been improved through the use of Eibach springs and a new AYC tune. This would be the last Lancer Evolution to feature the classic 4G63 engine and is the pinnacle of the 3rd wave Lancer Evolution cars.

gb.subtitle: 2014 GT Awards winner. A high-speed monster wearing the skin of a Camaro SS.
gb.description: Winner of the 2014 Gran Turismo Award. This 1970 Chevrolet Camaro SS has been customised by Roadster Shop in Illinois, United States. The basic construction has been recreated from scratch using carbon fibre and aluminium parts, and equipped with a 7L LS7 engine offset to the rear and tuned to 739.6 BHP. This power is matched by the stunning looks provided by its large overfenders, front spoiler and rear wing.

gb.subtitle: The final limited edition model of the RX-8, Mazda's rotary engine coupé with a unique 4-door design.
gb.description: Released in 2011, this is the final special edition model of the Mazda RX-8. The 6-speed manual Type RS base model, which features Bilstein shocks, and the 6-speed automatic Type E base model featuring luxuries like leather seats, have both been fitted with special interior and exterior furnishings. Originally slated for a run of 1,000 units, the announcement that the RX-8 would be discontinued in 2012 boosted sales, leading to an additional run of 1,000 more.

gb.subtitle: The very first Mercedes sports car with a characteristic boat tail.
gb.description: Double award winner at the 2017 Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance, taking both 'Best of Show' and the 'Gran Turismo Trophy'. Produced from 1926 to '33, what could be considered Mercedes-Benz's first sports car was designed by Ferdinand Porsche. It features a 7L supercharged straight six engine enveloped in beautiful 'boat tail' style bodywork by coachbuilder Barker.

gb.subtitle: Featuring the same S20 engine as the Skyline GT-R, this Fairlady Z is made for competition.
gb.description: Introduced in 1969 as the top grade model of the Fairlady Z, the Z 432 features an inline-6 DOHC 'S20' engine producing 157.8 BHP. This engine is based on that of Nissan's R380 race car and is capable of a 0-400 m time of 15.8s and a top speed of 130.5 mph. It also saw use in racing. Additionally, a Z 432 R model was sold in very small numbers and used fibreglass and acrylic parts to reduce weight.

gb.subtitle: Born on the battlefield, a demanding request from the US Army resulted in the father of the modern 4x4.
gb.description: The roots of the SUV category lie in this compact four-wheel drive car developed under a request by the US military in 1940. Of the test models produced by Bantam, Ford and Willys, the best performer was the Willys MB, an upgraded version of the MA, leading to the production of over 360,000 such cars. Its superb combination of simple, robust construction, using a ladder frame with rigid axles, and four-wheel drive would create a truly historic car, whose spirit has lived on for generations.

gb.subtitle: Engine displacement increased to 3.6L. This sports model is a lighter version of the 3rd generation 911 Carrera 2.
gb.description: In 1989, Porsche unveiled the 3rd generation 911, known as the type 964. Though styled almost identically to the previous 911, it was actually a major evolution with roughly 80% new parts. The four-wheel drive Carrera 4 was introduced first, with the rear-wheel drive Carrera 2 introduced in 1990. This Carrera RS is a performance tuned model based on the Carrera 2.

gb.subtitle: 2nd generation Impreza which was developed alongside the rally spec model.
gb.description: The first facelift of the GD Impreza is recognizable by its teardrop shaped 'blob eye' headlights. Engine efficiency has been increased through equal length matched exhaust headers. Some manual models also featured a Driver's Control Center Differential with auto mode. A further minor change in 2004 increased the tyre size and increased the torque output to 42.0 kgfm.

gb.subtitle: This Ferrari evolution model was produced in a limited run of just 32 cars.
gb.description: The FXX K is a track-only model developed from the LaFerrari and produced in a run of just 32 cars in 2014. It combines the 6.3L V12 engine from the LaFerrari with a 187.4 BHP electric motor for a total system output of 1,035.5 BHP. Aerodynamics have also been improved, and with the EVO kit installed, it produces 75% extra downforce. Untethered to any racing regulations, this car is able to provide the ultimate in driving performance.

gb.subtitle: This historic Ferrari flagship model wowed enthusiasts with its vivid design.
gb.description: Unveiled in 1984, the Testarossa was Ferrari's flagship midship layout model. The engine is a 5L 180 degree V12 unit producing a maximum 384.6 BHP power and 50.0 kgfm torque. It can accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in 5.8s, eventually reaching a top speed of 180.2 mph. The car's artistically elegant body, marked by its iconic 5-fin strakes and the rear fenders sharply jutting out from the compact cabin, have garnered a whole new generation of fans.

gb.subtitle: The World Endurance Championship winning Ford works machine.
gb.description: Released in 2015, the second generation Ford GT reimagining focuses on aerodynamics and speed with its compact V6 twin-turbo engine capable of a 0-62.1 mph time of 3.0s and a top speed of 216.2 mph. In racing, Chip Ganassi Racing of the United States competed in the FIA World Endurance Championship and the IMSA from 2016.

gb.subtitle: The midship sports car that paved the way for the celebrated Pantera.
gb.description: De Tomaso's second production midship sports car. To remedy the lack of power in the previous Vallelunga, this car is equipped with a Ford V8 engine. Thanks to its light weight at roughly 1.3 tons, the car is able to reach a top speed of 155.3 mph. The exterior which features a gullwing opening rear section was designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro in his Carrozzeria Ghia era. Just 401 of these cars were produced.

gb.subtitle: A hardcore sports version of the FIAT 500.
gb.description: The FIAT Abarth 595 was introduced in 1963. It was based on the 2nd gen FIAT 500 and tuned by Abarth. A further tuned model of the 595 would debut as the 595 Esseesse. Though it used the same engine displacement, compression was increased to improve power output to 31.6 BHP. With this extra performance in hand, the 595 series would see use in racing series across Europe, where it took the under 600 cc class by storm.

gb.subtitle: A 3.8L flat-6 engine producing 295.9 BHP. The most powerful model of the 993, the last air-cooled Porsche.
gb.description: The Porsche 911 reached its 4th generation model in 1993 with the release of the type 993. Along with an update to the styling, the suspension was also improved for better handling. The most powerful grade was the Carrera RS, introduced in 1995, which had a more rigid yet lighter body. It also featured the final air-cooled engine in a 993, a 3.8L flat-6 unit producing 295.9 BHP. A circuit-oriented Carrera RS Club Sport model was also available.

gb.subtitle: The car that brought Mercedes-Benz its first victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans.
gb.description: The 300 SL race car, codename W194, uses a tubular frame chassis with aluminium panels, and features tuned versions of the engine and running gear from the type W186 300. This car would claim victory for Mercedes-Benz in its debut race at the 1952 24 Hours of Le Mans. Its racing performance prompted calls for a production model, leading to the development of the road car.

gb.subtitle: This forefather of hot hatches is known for its high-energy handling.
gb.description: Debuting in 1971, the A112 Abarth is often considered one of the original hot hatches. It is based on the Autobianchi A112 and has been tuned by Abarth. It received a number of updates with the engine displacement increased in 1975, raising power output to 70 BHP, and an upgrade to a 5-speed transmission in 1979. Production ended in 1985, but it would find long-lasting support from enthusiasts enamoured with its spirited character.

gb.subtitle: This successor to the Dino 246 GT features a V8 engine in the midship position.
gb.description: Debuting in 1975, the 308 GTB served as the replacement for the Dino 246 GT and started a long-running trend of 2-seater V8 models. The elegant bodywork, which sits upon the steel, tube-based frame was designed by the same man who would go on to design numerous other Ferraris throughout the late 1960s to the early 1990s, Leonardo Fioravanti, who worked for Pininfarina at the time.

gb.subtitle: A 'High Boy' style hotrod displayed at the Henry Ford Museum.
gb.description: The roots of this car lie in the custom car and hot rod culture of the United States that dates back to the 1930s. Model T and Model B Fords would commonly be given bold exterior modifications and have their engines swapped for more powerful units. The engine of the 'V-3883' displayed in the Henry Ford Museum has been swapped for a 177.5 BHP Chrysler 331 Hemi. This car is relatively simple yet beautiful example, with the engine cover itself serving as an exterior accent.

gb.subtitle: This masterpiece of 60s sports car design made its name as the eponymous Bond car.
gb.description: The DB5 is a sports car by Aston Martin introduced in 1963. It was designed by Italy's Carrozzeria Touring using superleggera construction to reduce body weight. The engine produced 281.1 BHP on the standard model with the Vantage producing 313.6 BHP. It has been lauded as one of the super sports cars of the early 1960s. It also gained fame as the one of the 'Bond cars' featured in the 007 film series.

gb.subtitle: A French blue Porsche that raced the 1956 Le Mans.
gb.description: Sold from 1954, the 550/1500RS is a racing sports car featuring a steel tube frame with an aluminium body and a 4-cam flat-4 engine producing 133.1 BHP. It would achieve excellent results on the circuit, claiming class victory in both the 1954 and 1955 24 Hours of Le Mans. This 1500RS a particularly valuable example, featuring the same original paint that it wore at the 1956 24 Hours of Le Mans.

gb.subtitle: A lightweight cornering machine that has been called 'the best Aston Martin ever.'
gb.description: The Vantage proved to be a hit as a performance rear-wheel drive sports car. The model introduced in 2017 was almost identical in construction to the DB11 V8, but had a short wheelbase and was roughly 120 kg lighter, which gained it critical acclaim as the best handling car in corners in Aston Martin history. The engine is a Mercedes-AMG derived 4L V8 twin-turbo unit capable of a top speed of 195 mph (195.1 mph).

gb.subtitle: One of the last of the C7 Corvettes, and also the most powerful.
gb.description: The ZR1 was introduced towards the end of the C7 Corvette's run becoming the most powerful version. The 6.2L V8 supercharged 'LT5' engine now produced 754.4 BHP/969 Nm (98.8 kgfm). Aero parts were developed in conjunction with Pratt & Miller Engineering who ran the C7 in GT races, released in a lap time focused set or a top speed focused set. A car equipped with the top speed set was able to reach 214.9 mph.

gb.subtitle: A racing spec version of the GT-R for GT3 category competition.
gb.description: The Nissan GT-R NISMO GT3 is an FIA GT3 regulation production racing car based on the R35 model GT-R. The base model was later changed to the GT-R NISMO which used a dry sump system to lower the centre of gravity and optimize weight distribution. Extra front rigidity and newly designed suspension helped improve handling response. The changes to the engine room layout also improved cooling efficiency, which also helped with stability at high speeds.

gb.subtitle: The new WRC race car to carry on Toyota's strong rallying tradition.
gb.description: Developed by Toyota to compete in the WRC, the GR Yaris appears to be a simple compact car but is actually a powerful racing machine. Rigidity has been increased, body weight has been reduced and the centre of gravity has been lowered as far as possible. The four-wheel drive RZ model features a 1.6L 3-cylinder turbo engine with a 6-speed manual transmission. The 'RZ High performance' further adds an LSD to provide rocksteady traction. In January 2020, the '1st Edition' was introduced as special edition model.

gb.subtitle: This extreme hypercar is a modern reenvisioning of the classic 917, one of the most illustrious machines in Porsche history.
gb.description: The 917 achieved a number of glorious race results for Porsche, including winning 7 of 10 races at the 1970 World Sportscar Championship. The Porsche 917 LIVING LEGEND is a hypercar inspired by that 917. The classic façade of its design conceals a cutting-edge technology. Its high-level combination of top speed and downforce allow for rock-steady stability even at over 186.4 mph.

gb.subtitle: A homologation model that once claimed victory in the DTM. The blister fenders are a testimony to its performance.
gb.description: This homologation model was developed from the 3 Series model at the time for the purpose of competing in touring car racing. Using the 2-door sedan model as a base, the track width was increased and aerodynamic improvements were made including adjusting the angle of the rear wing. Starting with a 2.3L inline-4 DOHC engine, changes were made each year eventually resulting in the final 2.5L 'Sport Evolution' model.

gb.subtitle: A lightweight model of the 3.0 CS sports coupé, all excess equipment has been removed to maximise on-track performance.
gb.description: In 1968, BMW released the 2800 CS sports coupé which featured a powerful 2.8 straight six engine. In 1971 came the 3.0 CS, an updated model with a larger engine. Having decided to enter the 3.0 CS in races, BMW developed a lightweight model for homologation purposes named the 3.0 CSL. The 'L' of this name stands for 'light.'

gb.subtitle: This definitive Japanese hot hatch now handles better than ever.
gb.description: The Swift Sport is a sports model of the 4th generation Suzuki Swift, introduced in 2016. The aerodynamic body is equipped with a tuned downsized 1.4L turbo engine running on high-octane fuel. The suspension has also been specially tuned to improve handling. It should also be noted that this model is 70 kg lighter than the previous Swift Sport model.

gb.subtitle: A different facet of Alpine: a 3 Litre V8 Le Mans car.
gb.description: Thanks to the efforts of the A110, Alpine is well known as a rallying brand, but in the 1960s they also developed prototype racing cars which found success on the circuit. Of those, the car that had the greatest chance of overall victory at the 24 Hours of Le Mans was the A220 which debuted in 1968. In the actual race the car was plagued by troubles and unable to achieve the desired result, but it is still remembered by fans as one of the classic Alpines.

gb.subtitle: The most powerful model of the 4th gen. C-Class line-up, featuring a 4L twin-turbo V8 engine.
gb.description: A high-performance model of the 4th generation C Class. Though it shares the same name as the previous C63, a few major changes have been made, including switching the naturally aspirated 6.2L V8 engine for a 4L twin-turbo configuration. This new engine is the same as the one used in the AMG GT, but the maximum torque has been increased and the range lowered to fit the weight and purpose of the vehicle. The 'C63 S Coupé' is a circuit-oriented performance model.

gb.subtitle: This super sports car is a reinterpretation of the glorious Carrera GT as a plug-in hybrid.
gb.description: The Porsche 918 Spyder is a super sports car released by Porsche in 2011. Succeeding the Carrera GT, it was sold in a limited run of 918 units as per its name. Its most notable feature is that it is a plug-in hybrid. The midship-mounted 599.6 BHP 4.6L V8 engine is assisted by 2 electric motors on the front axle, and one on the rear for a total system output of up to 873.8 BHP.

gb.subtitle: This extreme sports package was introduced for later models of the GTO, the original muscle car.
gb.description: Introduced in 1968, the 2nd generation Pontiac GTO is said to be one of the originators of the muscle car, but it had many powerful rivals. 'The Judge' was a sports package designed to end the argument. The package, which included a 6.6L V8 'Ram Air III' engine, Hurst shifter, heavy duty suspension, wide tyres and a rear spoiler, put the GTO back on the top spot.

gb.subtitle: The origin of the American sports car. The glorious first gen. Corvette.
gb.description: In the early 1950s, the American sports car market was largely dominated by European models. This was when Chevrolet would release the original Corvette. The very first models featured an advanced body design with a steel frame and fibreglass panels, equipped with a 149.9 BHP 3.8L straight six engine. While originally only produced in a limited run of 300 units, the car would prove to be a massive success and full scale production began in 1954. The power output was increased to 152.9 BHP and the 1958 model introduced the quad headlights.

gb.subtitle: A Cosworth tuned masterpiece that dominated touring car racing.
gb.description: The Sierra RS Cosworth was created in 1995 by the masters at Cosworth. Originally a family car, the Sierra’s 2L inline-4 engine was fully tuned, adding a DOHC head and turbocharger, along with other chassis upgrades. The Sierra RS500 Cosworth was introduced a year later. Between 1988 and 1990, it competed in Group A category races around the world, winning several championship titles.

gb.subtitle: A limited-edition Civic Type R with special tuning.
gb.description: The 5th Type R model Honda Civic was released in 2017. Previous models had simply aimed to increase the performance of the base model Civic, but the 5th generation Type R was developed from the ground up alongside the base model. The 'Limited Edition' model, released in 2020, had its performance increased further. The weight has been reduced by 20 kg through the removal of soundproofing and the use of special forged wheels. Minor adjustments have also been made to the suspension. The worldwide limited run of 1,000 units sold out almost immediately.

gb.subtitle: The ultimate naturally aspirated flat 6. A meticulously crafted machine made by RUF.
gb.description: This RUF original is based on the 991 model Porsche 911 GT3. Built around the theme of combining GT3 performance with road car comfort, this car features a naturally aspirated Mezger engine, assembled with the legendary GT1 crank, and enlarged from 3.8L to 4.2L. The exterior is accented by rivetted overfenders which serve to clearly state the car's ferocity. An excellent choice for a gentleman driver.

gb.subtitle: The pinnacle of V8 Ferraris with the heart of a 488 Pista.
gb.description: The Ferrari F8 Tributo was unveiled in 2019 as the successor to the 488 GTB. While externally similar to the 488, major changes have been made to aerodynamic details changing its overall image. The 3.9L V8 twin-turbo engine produces 710.1 BHP allowing for a 0-62.1 mph time of 2.9s and a top speed of 211.3 mph making it the fastest ever V8 model. Thanks to latest in body control devices, this car is also exceptionally easy to drive.

gb.subtitle: Adopting the classic V12 FR layout, this Ferrari achieves blinding speed while retaining usability.\t
gb.description: The 812 Superfast was introduced in 2017 to continue Ferrari's lineage of front-engined V12 models. This car is Ferrari's first to use electric-power steering and has inherited an improved version of the 4-wheel steering system from the F12berlinetta, which means that despite its relatively long 2,720 mm wheelbase, the car is still capable of tight turns.

gb.subtitle: The WRC base model with an aluminium bonnet and rear spoiler.
gb.description: The 6th generation Toyota Celica was introduced in October 1993. The futuristic stylings of the Celica were further clarified with its quad round headlights, while changes like the larger body strengthened its image as a front-wheel drive speciality car. In 1994, the GT-FOUR (ST205) was introduced as a WRC base car. The 3S-GTE 2L turbo engine has been tuned to produce 251.5 BHP.

gb.subtitle: The successor to the ultra high performance Veyron.
gb.description: The Chiron is a super sports car by Bugatti, introduced in 2016. Sold in worldwide limited run of 500 cars, this car effectively serves as the successor to the Veyron. The carbon fibre chassis exhibits the same level of rigidity as an LMP1 race car, and the 8L W16 quad-turbo engine from the Veyron has been tuned to produce 1,479.3 BHP with 163.1 kgfm max. torque. It is able to accelerate from 0-62.1 mph in 2.5s and a prototype model set an actual top speed of 304.8 mph.

gb.subtitle: Cornering better than ever before. A BRZ for the Super GT.
gb.description: From 2012, Subaru began competing with the BRZ in Japan's domestic 'Super GT' racing series GT300 class. Following the introduction of the base model's 2nd generation in 2021, Subaru switched over to a new GT machine based on 2nd gen BRZ. It carried over the strengths of the old model like the EJ20 engine, while implementing improvements to weight distribution and aerodynamics. In 2021, the BRZ was crowned the GT300 class series champion in a historic first for Subaru.

gb.subtitle: A legendary F1 machine that marked the end of the Turbo era.
gb.description: This McLaren race car competed in the 1988 F1 World Championship. The chassis was designed by Gordon Murray and Steve Nichols and is powered by a Honda RA168E engine. It would win 15 of the 16 races that season. The No. 12 MP4/4 was driven by Ayrton Senna. Senna performed extremely well, scoring 13 pole positions and 8 race victories to claim the drivers title.

gb.subtitle: A super sports car combining the heart of the Hayabusa with electric motors.
gb.description: The SUZUKI Vision Gran Turismo utilises the latest engine from the 'Hayabusa' sports bike, along with the latest electrification and weight reduction technologies. The powertrain uses the 1,340 cm³ engine of the Hayabusa along with 3 high-power electric motors in an all-wheel drive configuration. The engine and motors combined provide a total output of 426 BHP at 9,700 rpm, making this a compact super sports machine.

gb.subtitle: The popular grade model of the S15; equipped with side and rear spoilers as standard.
gb.description: The 7th generation S15 Silvia returned to a more compact model similar to the S13, transforming into an affordable rear-wheel drive sports car. It carried over the SR20 from the models before it, but the running gear and suspension received a major overhaul. Increased body rigidity, upgraded brakes, sportier suspension and a helical LSD all provided a much higher level of performance than its predecessors.

gb.subtitle: Porsche's modern yet daring statement on the future of the sports car.
gb.description: This lightweight hyper performance machine carries on the traditions of Porsche while providing a message to the future of sports cars. The exterior and interior seamlessly blend together to create the most immersive driving experience possible. The power unit uses dual electric motors, while the novel active aero system adapts to provide the optimum aerodynamics for the conditions at hand.

gb.subtitle: A roadster that's an heir to the legendary D-Type.
gb.description: Jaguar's third Vision Gran Turismo takes inspiration from the Jaguar D-type. This electric open single seater with aero screen is powered by 3 electric motors producing over 986.2 BHP. Behind the seat is a modern interpretation of the classic D-type's iconic fin, and the focused cockpit controls also represent the history and traditions of Jaguar.

gb.subtitle: A tuned up Gr.4 version of the Swift Sport based on the 'KATANA Edition'.
gb.description: A Gr.4 version of the 'KATANA Edition' concept model, which combines the ZC33 model Swift Sport with the beauty and power of the KATANA sports bike. The front under spoiler has been extended and a GT style wing has been added. Along with different sized tyres, interior weight reduction, and a roll cage, the car has evolved into a Gran Turismo Gr.4 spec race machine.

gb.subtitle: A bigger engine but with the same concepts behind it. Japan's representative lightweight FR sports car.
gb.description: Toyota's lightweight, front-engine rear-wheel drive sports car, named '86', was introduced in 2012 and sold over 200,000 units worldwide. 9 years since its release, the car was reborn as the 'GR86', featuring a larger 2.4L naturally aspirated 4-cylinder DOHC boxer engine producing 231.8 BHP and 25.5 kgfm maximum torque. With improvements to body rigidity and weight reduction, along with a new aerodynamic design created from motorsports feedback, this car is more fun to drive than ever before.

gb.subtitle: The globally successful Volvo that serves as a saloon, estate, and coupe.
gb.description: The V40 is a 5-door hatchback model in the C-segment. Taking design cues from Volvo classics of the 1960s, like the P1800 and 1800ES, the flowing lines of its silhouette can be interpreted as either a coupé or a wagon. The T5 R-Design is the most sporty model in the series lineup. The 2L inline-5 turbo engine produced 210.1 BHP while the sports suspension and 18-inch wheels provide sharp yet smooth handling.

gb.subtitle: A hardboiled FR that hides the power of a demon in its compact body.
gb.description: This ferocious beast puts the S55 3L straight six twin-turbo engine from the M3/M4 in the 2 Series coupé body. The stretched out fenders hint at the power within, but just a short sprint is enough to fully unleash its power as the turbochargers spool up. The suspension uses aluminium components to reduce unsprung weight. The torque vectoring Active M Differential allows the car to conquer any corner at will.

gb.subtitle: Filled with motorsports knowhow, this is the ultimate version of the AMG GT.
gb.description: This ultimate sports car is one of several evolutions of the AMG GT that had come since its introduction in 2014. The 4L V8 engine has been specially tuned to increase both power and torque, reaching 719.9 BHP and 800Nm (81.57 kgfm) respectively. The construction and materials used in the suspension have also been overhauled for the best possible handling and cornering performance. Another selling point is its racing car style bodywork.

gb.subtitle: A Demon born simply to run the quarter-mile as fast as possible.
gb.description: The 3rd generation Dodge Challenger was introduced in 2008 to carry on the legacy of the original Challenger, itself a masterpiece muscle car. A number of high performance models were released since its debut, but the star of the lineup came in 2018. This was the SRT Demon, a monster machine created for the sole purpose of winning drag races. Tuned to produce 840.2 BHP on 100 octane or higher fuel, it can run the quarter mile in a staggering 9.65s.

gb.subtitle: A NASCAR homologation version of the original Mustang that was only produced for 2 years.
gb.description: This high performance model was only available on the 1969 and 1970 models of Ford's original Mustang. Produced for NASCAR homologation, it featured the largest engine displacement in a Mustang with a 7L V8 429 unit. Easily recognisable by the large bonnet scoop, it is often called the most powerful Mustang in history.

gb.subtitle: A motorsport focused Cayman with the power of the 911.
gb.description: The Cayman GT4 is a motorsports oriented model that was added to the Porsche Cayman lineup in 2015. The engine is based on the 3.8L flat-6 from the 911 Carrera S, attached to a 6-speed manual transmission. Producing 379.7 BHP, it is more powerful than the base 911 Carrera and also features brake and suspension parts from the 991 model 911 GT3. A roll cage and 6-point seatbelts were also available as options.

gb.subtitle: A beautiful streamlined 2 seater sportscar that won the Gran Turismo Trophy.
gb.description: This Maserati A6GCS/53 Spyder won the 'Gran Turismo Trophy' at the 2014 Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance. The beautiful aluminium Spyder body was created by Carrozzeria Fantuzzi, while the 167.7 BHP engine was made by Gioacchino Colombo. It competed under the Maserati factory team, winning 5 class victories and 3 overall victories across the 1954 season.

gb.subtitle: A masterpiece that brought great success to Porsche's GT racing efforts in the 1960's.
gb.description: In 1963, Porsche developed Carrera GTS in accordance with the World Sportscar Championship regulations of the time. In order to clear the 100-production-unit homologation requirement, the car used a ladder-frame chassis with a lightweight fibreglass body. It had excellent performance and won many of the major races, starting with the Targa Florio, and became the backbone of Porsche's GT racing efforts of the 1960s.

gb.subtitle: An extraordinary Skyline that stood out in races of the 1980's.
gb.description: The Skyline Super Silhouette is a silhouette formula car (a race car that only uses the basic shape of the production model) based on the 6th generation Skyline. Adorned with wide front and rear fenders and a large rear wing, the body houses 2.1L 4-cylinder turbo 'LZ20B' racing engine. This car would claim 8 wins between 1982 and 1984.

gb.subtitle: Japan's premium mini van that evolved into a high class luxury car.
gb.description: Since the introduction of the original model in 2002, the Toyota Alphard has constantly strived to provide the definitive luxury minivan. The 3rd generation Alphard, introduced in 2015, added the 'Executive Lounge' luxury upgrade which provides the utmost in comfort for the 2nd row seats. It provided more luxury and comfort than ever before. In 2017, a facelift model was released which provided an update to the 4.5L V6 engine along with further improving comfort.

gb.subtitle: An elegant concept model with a next-generation rotary engine.
gb.description: A rotary sports concept unveiled at the 2015 Tokyo Motor Show. All unnecessary lines and faces have been chiselled away from the elegant long nose, short deck form to create Mazda's vision of the ideal rear-wheel drive sports car. Equipped with the SKYACTIV-R next-generation rotary engines, the car provides a vision of the future of rotary power.
